B00004W510|5.0|<br />Perhaps no musical group exemplified an anti-counter cultural approach to music better than The Band did in various ways. They influenced many people who were influential in their own right either at the time (Eric Clapton and George Harrison's approach to music) or would be in years to come (i.e. Roger Waters' approach to concept album writing with Pink Floyd) not to mention being one of the begetters of 1970's style \\"folk country.\\" And while more could be said about them than that, there is plenty to say about this album and that is where the review will be focused.  <br /> <br />The album opens with \\"Across the Great Divide\\" and it sets the tone for the very down home Americana feel of this album full of uniformly excellent songs. The latter song contains the story of a man who tries to explain himself to his woman and recounts to some extent the recklessness of his \\"younger days\\" as he tries to persuade her to not kill herself. It is not as grim as it sounds in words I assure you.  <br /> <br />The second song is \\"Rag Mama Rag\\" which is a fun quirky song with fiddles, an offbeat drum pattern, a mandolin, a fiddle instead of bass, and the bass parts played on a tuba. The lyrics of the song were about a woman who only wants to play ragtime music...there may be a sly message in that but whatever. That brings us to one of the best songs on the album. <br /> <br />\\"The Night They Drove Old Dixie Down\\" is musically and lyrically a masterpiece. It is ironic a Canadian songwriter (Jaime Robbie Robertson) could write such an empathetic tune about the old South but it the power of the song cannot be denied. It was delivered with conviction by the only American in the group (the southerner Levon Helm). Garth Hudson gets some very textural sounds with a melodica overdubbed via his Lowrey organ, which sounds like a harmonica starting with the second verse of the song. It is an example of the multifaceted talents of the Band's members -all of whom except Robbie Robertson played multiple instruments. I never get tired of hearing this song, singing it, or playing it on guitar. It is followed by \\"When You Awake\\", a song with lyrics are about family and remembering with grandfatherly advice being given.  <br /> <br />From there the album moves to \\"Up on Cripple Creek\\" which is a song with a very \\"back porch\\" feel which is (I must say it) deliciously sleazy in a way. Garth Hudson is playing a clavinet through a wah wah pedal to create the sound of a jew's harp. When mixed with Danko's bass playing, it gives a significantly low range to the tune about a narrative of a man who wants to lookup an old girlfriend for \\"assistance\\" if you will and how in many areas she completes him. \\"Whispering Pines\\" follows, which Robertson co-wrote with Richard Manuel. The song has a completely different tempo than the one preceding it and Manuel delivers a very wrenching vocal performance vocally and on piano.  <br /> <br />Following \\"Whispering Pines\\" is \\"Jemima Surrender\\" which has a heavier tempo with boogie-woogie piano (played not by Manuel but by Hudson), Manuel on drums, Levon Helm not on drums but rhythm guitar, and Robertson on lead guitar. (The alternate take --half the songs on the album have an alternative take on this CD- has the members on their usual instruments for a completely different approach to the song.) The song is about the singer wanting a girl named Jemima to give in and...well...that is all I will tell you about it. <br /> <br />\\"Rocking Chair\\" is possibly my favourite song on the album. It is unconventional musically for the group in that there is no drums (Helm is on mandolin on this tune), Hudson plays accordion, Robertson is on acoustic guitar, and the timekeeping is done solely by Danko's bass and that is adequate. The lyrics I find to be quite haunting now in the wake of having lost my childhood best friend last year and for other reasons not to be mentioned here. <br /> <br />\\"Look Out Cleveland\\" is a up tempo rocker sung by Danko with some aggressive lead fills by Robertson backed by Danko's equally aggressive bass picking and is about \\"a storm coming through\\" which ends up devastating everything. (Compared to everything else on the album, this song stands out in its strident phrasing.) <br /> <br />From there the next song is \\"Jawbone\\" and it opens with a very slow start and alternates time signatures from verses to the pre-chorus to the chorus and back again with lyrics about a thief who is unrepentant. The album next moves into \\"Unfaithful Servant\\" which is sung by Danko and is a slow creeper about...well...exactly what the title says and the narrator tries to examine the reason for the faithlessness involved.  <br /> <br />The album ends officially with \\"King Harvest\\" which is a frantic tune sung by Manuel. The song has an unusual sound even for an album of songs many of which are distinctive in that sense. The shifting tempos from verse to verse gives a distinctive sound as does Robertson's stinging lead playing which shows a pleasing restraint to it. The lyrics show the tensions of paradoxical attachments (city and country, past and present, etc) and is a tale about a union man who is feeling the pinch ala Steinbeck's \\"Grapes of Wrath\\" and wraps up the album quite strongly.  <br /> <br />There are also alternate takes of six of the songs on the CD release as well as an outtake of a song that would appear on future albums (referring to \\"Get Up Jake\\"). But the twelve songs on the album as originally released are the focus of this review and they all cohere well making this album a must have for anyone who likes good music. <br />
0451527046|5.0|I read this book as a child, and was getting fuzzy on the details, so recently re-read this famous tale. I can assure you that it is more than worthy of its status in literature. Jim Hawkins is a young boy who meets up with a strange and sickly traveler who stays at the Inn for which he is working. The sailor -known as Billy Bones -dies in the night. Upon searching the contents of the dead sailor, a map is found - a treasure map no less! From there we follow the adventures of young Jim as he meets the secretive Long John Silver and his insightful talking parrot on the quest for gold. What mysteries and turns of fate lay waiting for them on Treasure Island? This is a relatively short book, but there is great adventure waiting if you are willing to set your sails for this masterpiece.<br /><br />Relic113
B00005JMJG|4.0|I purchased this DVD after hearing a local radio DJ discuss it on the air. I wasn't certain what to expect, asI've never been a fan of Jim Carrey's work. What I found however, was an intense, powerful performance of a seemingly tragic character (Joel), coupled with an incredible performance by Kate Winslet (Clementine).<br /><br />This film is made in a stream-of-consciousness approach, so I was glad I watched it in mid-afternoon, when I am most awake and alert. I had to think at some of the memory flashes as to whether or not they were a dream, reality, skewed reality, or what. At times the plot-line was hurt because of the constant leaps from one place in time to another. This jumping makes some of the movie hard-to-follow and disjunct.<br /><br />Overall, though, I did enjoy this and would recommend it. I think \\"Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind\\" raises some interesting questions dealing wtih our emotions and our own humanity, and I think it is a film that should endure any criticism it receives.

B000002KHH|5.0|Back in the early 70's, there was an unknown band named Polka Tulk, that played Folk Rock. Luckily for them and for us, they dropped the name AND the sound, and became known as Black Sabbath, one of the prime inventors and innovators of Heavy Metal. Parents everywhere were freaking out (I can only imagine how many people wanted to shut this band down) about satanic messages (you know, the usual bulls**t parents do about a Heavy Metal band), and bats getting heads bitten off (hehehe), but they couldn't stop them, and to this day, people are STILL discovering Black Sabbath for the first time, people are STILL getting turned onto REAL Metal thanks to this band, and people are STILL listening to \\"Iron Man\\" for the first time. THAT is staying power, people, and not too many bands have the stuff it takes to still be making LOTS of cash off of a CD you released nearly 40 years ago.  <br /> <br />Not only was Black Sabbath the premiere Heavy Metal Band (along with Zeppelin and Deep Purple), but they were incredibly talented. Their original lineup (which, unfortunately, didn't last very long, as they had enough lineup changes to drive you crazy!) consisted of: Tony Iommi (Guitars)-One of the most popular guitarists out there. He has the most kick ass riffs you've ever heard and had great solos. Bill Ward (Drums)-He was one of the greatest drummers to live, and was very technically skilled behind the kit. His instrumental studio drum solo \\"Rat Salad\\" is one of the best, right up there with John Bonham's \\"Moby Dick\\". Geezer Butler (Bass)-Don't let the weird name fool you, this guy is AMAZING on the bass. He IS, not might me, but IS the greatest Metal bassist out there. Despite the sub-par production, which might kind of drown out the bass, making it hard to hear sometimes (hey, give 'em a break, it was they 70's),  the bass still somehow manages to stand out. Especially in songs like \\"Hand Of Doom\\" and \\"Jack The Stripper/Fairies Wear Boots\\". Ozzy Osbourne (Vocals)-Does Ozzy really even need an introduction? I mean, he was the first Heavy Metal frontman, what more do you need to know? If you STILL don't know who Ozzy is (EVEN after his numerous awards and compilation albums from his solo career(as well as with Black Sabbath), AND the whole bat thing), you really should come out of that cave you've been living in for so long. For the past 20 or so years (maybe even 30), its been almost impossible to escape news of the crazy man behind Black Sabbath. While his voice isn't exactly powerful, or even that good, his stage presence more than makes up for it.  <br /> <br />Now for song ratings: <br /> <br />1.\\"War Pigs/Luke's Wall\\" - One of the most popular Sabbath tracks, and for good reason. What's not to like about this song? Complex drumming, guitar solos, one of the greatest riffs on the planet, GOOD bass playing, and soaring vocals with lyrics that you can tell were actually thought about, and not just thrown together (A side note-I'm guessing this is one of the first peices of political lyrics ever written. Not sure of that though, I might be wrong). (10/10) <br /> <br />2.\\"Paranoid\\" - A pretty straightforward track. Short, sweet, and to the point. Good drumming, good guitar work. That's all, not TOO much of a standout track. (8/10) <br /> <br />3.\\"Planet Caravan\\" - To be honest, I'm not too sure what to classify this song. Its not really a ballad, nor is it a Rock 'n' Roll track. It's still a greatly addicting song. (9.5/10) <br /> <br />4.\\"Iron Man\\" - THE most popular Sabbath song, and one of the most popular songs of all time. This song is flawless. Forget the fact that Sabbath \\"fans\\" say its overrated, because that has nothing to do with the actual song itself, this song is absolutely flawless. The only thing that they could have worked on would've been better production (remaster maybe?). (10/10) <br /> <br />5.\\"Electric Funeral\\" - Great song. Nothing about this song really stands-out to me, but its still a great piece of work. (8/10)<br /> <br />6.\\"Hand Of Doom\\" - Strongest bass performance on the album. Great job by Butler. The same thing goes for this song. Not a real standout song. (8/10) <br /> <br />7.\\"Rat Salad\\" - Legendary drum performance by a legendary drummer. Very good song if you like drum solos and the like, otherwise, this might be the worst song on the album for the average Sabbath fan. It gets a ten from me though, since I find drum solos incredibly entertaining. (10/10) <br /> <br />8.\\"Jack The Stripper/Fairies Wear Boots\\" - One of my favorites off the album. Also a very good and popular song that is nearly flawless. One of the strongest bass performances on the album, and a perfect way to end an album like this. (10/10) <br /> <br />Overall: (73.5/80) Not a bad score at all. None of the songs got below a seven, because even the not so amazing songs are too good to be that low. If you don't have this album, shame on you, go out and buy it as soon as possible, you wimp!

B000002IMG|5.0|Testament was a very interesting Thrash band. They were influenced by Metallica, Megadeth, and Slayer (not so much by Slayer), but they were also almost as good as them. Testament's sophomore 1988 release, \\"The New Order\\" was actually the album that put them on the spot for one of The Big Four of Thrash (Gosh, man, what an honor to beat out Anthrax, Slayer, AND Megadeth). Although that title didn't last long, Testament still produced some of the finest Thrash Metal ever. This was their best work by far. They had everything you could want from a Speed/Thrash Metal band. Speed (obviously), GREAT guitar work, awesome drumming, and their vocalist ain't half bad either.    The lineup for this band consisted of: Chuck Billy (Vocals)- He originally replaced Steve Souza, who quit the band right before recording to join Exodus (another fine Thrash band). He's got some decent vocal work on this album. Not really too strong though, definately intimidating. Alex Skolnick (Lead Guitars)-Probably the most talented person in the band. He ranks as one of the best Metal guitarists ever, and Testament was very lucky to have him. Its very unfortunate he left the band a couple albums later to join Savatage, due to \\"creative limitations\\". Eric Peterson (Guitars)-Very good rhythm guitarist. Great riffs, good speed, decent. Skolnick buries him in the dust, though. Derrick Ramirez (Guitars)-Same thing goes for him. Not as good as Skolnick, but decent. Greg Christian (Bass)-The basslines are mean, and he does a really good job. The production is good enough to actually hear the bass, and thats always a good thing. Louis Clemente (Drums)-Very talented drummer that has plenty of speed and rhythm. The drumwork is actually one of the more impressive things about the album.    Now for song ratings:    1.\\"Eerie Inhabitants\\" - Well, it sure is Eerie, but the intro is so long, that by the time it picks up, you've probably already skipped the song. Its still good though. (9/10)    2.\\"The New Order\\"- Things finally start kicking up with the title track. Just like with every band's album, the title track for this album is promising, and is one of the best on the album. (10/10)    3.\\"Trial By Fire\\" - Things keep going strong with the thrid track. It's not that its bad, I just don't really think much of this song. Something is missing, but I can't figure it out. Still a good song, though. (7.5/10)    4.\\"Into The Pit\\" - This song is SUCH a great headbanger! You really get the feeling you're in the pit when you listen to this song. This is a great song to play live, I'm sure. Its nearly flawless, and the best on the album in my opinion. (10/10)    5.\\"Hypnosis\\" - I cant actually rate this song, due to the fact that it isn't a song. It's basically just a guitar interlude.    6.\\"Disciples Of The Watch\\" - This is actually Testament's most popular song, and for good reason. It got everything you need. I especially like the guitar work, its some of the best on the album, and the riffs are just kick-ass. (10/10)    7.\\"The Preacher\\" - This sounds like a different Testament. Maybe because this is the only song Steve Souza actually recorded his voice on before he left. You can easily tell right when you hear the first word. Still classic Testament, and still a good song, the vocals are just a little more harsh and unmelodic though. (9/10)    8.\\"Nobody's Fault\\" - Great song. Nothing special about it though. Kind of filler. The vocals especially remind me of Dave Mustaine, because he's so snarly on here. (8/10)    9.\\"A Day Of Reckoning\\" - Great song with amazing guitar work, and sounds a lot like the earlier tracks. Good song. (9.5/10)    10.\\"Musical Death (A Dirge)\\" - I love the acoustic work. Its basically an instrumental with a couple of random heavy parts and great guitar work throughout. Its another one of those \\"eerie\\" tracks, which is always a good thing. (8/10)    Overall: (72/80). A great album worth checking out, especially if you love Bay Area Thrash, where the planet's best Thrash comes from. If you're a Thrash band from somewhere else other than the Bay Area, chances are, you're not that good (And I'm saying that as a person who actually lives in the Bay Area).
B00004XONN|4.0|\\"Kid A\\" can basically be viewed as the third installment of a trilogy that began with \\"The Bends,\\" and followed by \\"OK Computer,\\" in that Radiohead's music \\"evolved\\" from using the standard rock and roll instruments (i.e. electric lead and rhythm guitar, bass and drums) to greater reliance on electronica and Eno/Fripp-type soundscapes.  \\"Kid A,\\" though not as monumental as the band's masterwork \\"OK Computer,\\" nevertheless stands out as a terrific album, and, in my opinion, just misses a five star rating, because it could have benefited from one more song of a similar quality to \\"Optimistic.\\"    I detect a theme to this album, reflected in the bizarre artwork, namely an individual's disconnect from life, while still attempting to go throught the motions (sort of like how one might feel after taking too much Benadryl).  Interestingly, Radiohead also takes up a cause, reflected in the liner notes (ala U2 and REM): \\"ice melt around the world,\\" which is a serious environmental problem and future disaster waiting to happen (no doubt related, in part, to the greenhouse effect, caused by certain air pollutants).    With \\"Kid A,\\" Thom Yorke, once again, demonstrates how evocative repetition of a phrase can be.  Let's take the opening track, for instance.  If Yorke just sang: \\"Everything in its right place\\" once, one might interpret this at face value.  But instead, Yorke sings \\"Everything, everything, everything, in its right place, in its right place, in its right place.\\"  See the difference?  Now we get an image of a person acting obsessively to make sure everything is perfectly placed.  Couple this with the insect noises simultaneously heard (in fact, at the end of the song the word \\"everything\\" is transformed into a buzzing sound) and we have something quite disturbing.  Examples of dramatic effect through repetition of phrases can be found in almost every song on \\"Kid A.\\"    Half of the tracks on the album are more like soundscapes than songs, reminiscent of Eno and Fripp (\\"Everything in its Right Place,\\" \\"Kid A,\\" \\"Treefingers,\\" \\"In Limbo,\\" \\"Motion Picture Soundtrack\\").  My favorite song on the album though, and probably the most \\"accessible\\" track, is \\"Optimistic\\" (\\"If you try the best you can, if you try the best you can, the best you can is good enough\\") which is one of my three favorite Radiohead songs, together with \\"Paranoid Android\\" and \\"Karma Police.\\"     I also like the bass heavy \\"National Anthem\\" with its startling horns (although it's a little too long), and the mock-disco \\"Idioteque.\\"  \\"How to Disappear Completely,\\" ranks as one of their better quiet songs, along the same lines as \\"Fake Plastic Trees\\" from \\"The Bends,\\" and \\"Let Down\\" from \\"OK Computer.\\"  \\"Everything in its Right Place,\\" perfectly introduces and sets the tone for everything that follows.    \\"Kid A\\" was a worthy follow-up to \\"OK Computer,\\" and that, by itself, is all that really needs to be said.

0143034901|5.0|With Shadow of the Wind, Carlos Ruiz Zafon has penned a work that is a work of art.  Set in mid-twentieth century Spain, the book's focal character is Daniel, a antique book dealer's son.  When he is taken to \\"The Cemetery of Lost Books\\" by his father, he is instructed to pick out of book from the thousands present.  He picks \\"The Shadow of the Wind\\" by Julian Carax.  He is told that when you pick a book from the \\"cemetery\\" you become a part of it and it becomes part of you.<br /><br />After he reads the book, he decides to look for more books by the author.  He is told that very few if any remain. In fact, someone has been systematically destroying Carax' works.<br /><br />As he investigates, he uncovers many years worth of mystery, lost love and intrigue revolving around Julian Carax.<br /><br />More than a novel, this book is a poem to books and book lovers everywhere.
B000BYA5GO|3.0|Yuri Orlov (Nicolas Cage) is a young second generation Ukrainian living in New York's Little Odessa. Life is tough for Yuri; frustrated and poor, he realizes that he's not really that good at anything, with the world pretty much offering him a ticket to know where. When we first meet him, around 1982, he is longing to bust out of the kosher restaurant owned by his father, who fervently keeps up the charade of being Jewish that he invented so he could get his family expelled from the Soviet Union. <br /> <br />I guess when you're raised on a lie; it becomes pretty easy to keep the pretense up. Yuri, recognizing he has a talent for being in the wrong place at the right time, hatches a plan with his kid-brother Vitali (Jared Leto) to sell arms and ammunitions: \\"that was the day I realized my destiny lay in fulfilling another basic human need.\\" Of course, there isn't much business for this kind of thing in the States, so Yuri and Vitali find themselves doing business in Berlin during the height of the Cold War.  <br /> <br />Their criminal trade eventually takes them to South America, where Vitali gets hooked on coke, and where, for the first time, they meet their arch nemesis Jack Valentine (Ethan Hawke), an idealistic Interpol agent.  But the bulk of Yuri's fortune is made when the Soviet Union crumbles and its vast cache of weapons is made available to him. <br /> <br />Now Yuri is free to sell his product to war torn Africa, where he becomes professionally entangled with Liberian president Andre Baptiste (Eamonn Walker), a kind of Charles Taylor-like fanatical dictator. Along the way Yuri becomes a very rich man adopting a glamorous supermodel trophy wife Ava (Bridget Moynahan) and tries to help his brother Vitali beat his steady addiction to cocaine and alcohol.  <br /> <br />Director Andrew Nichol's movie is unapologetically purposeful, and his subject matter is incendiary and also quite timely. The devastating consequences of the weapons trade are well known, andLord of War is a forceful film with a lot on its mind. Then why is the film so flat and un-involving? Perhaps because it's all so convoluted - Nichol probably has enough material here for five movies, consequently his narrative never complete meshes; it's as though Lord of War is a film in search of a decent plot.  <br /> <br />It doesn't help that Yuri is played by Cage, one of the most over-rated actors of his generation, doing his usual softly spoken, puppy dog shtick; he blusters when he should be quiet and raves when he should be contemplative. When the dialogue isn't enough to provide the facts, Nichol stuffs Yuri's mouth with cynical, and contemptuous narration to describe the dirty business in detail, but you really have to worry about a film when Yuri's verbal announcements are far more intriguing than the fictional plot devices used to provide human drama. <br /> <br />I guess you could say that Lord of War is mildly intriguing when it deals with the nuts and bolts of the weapons business, and it often sails along with a nifty, amoral irreverence. But it's just too overly didactic and preachy, ultimately sinking under the weight of it's own message and pretensions. What really does this film in is the director's penchant for turning Yuri into a character that we should care about.  <br /> <br />There are a few cheeky moments complete with some funny lines, but after forty minutes or so, it all becomes terribly repetitive. After all, we've got the message in the opening credits, which follow the life of a bullet from the factory to the forehead of a third-world teenager. Mike Leonard January 06.  <br />

0743454529|5.0|Few deny the subject matter and majority of the book were enthralling, with some being mystified by the ending. but, what a story. <br /> <br />What it said to me was strive to provide a fantastic life for your kids, enjoy every second of your children's lives and make damn sure they know that you adore them because it has the potential to be blown away with one event.  take the time to think about your children even if you hit a crisis point. love them, find time for them. <br /> <br />this book will most likely make you cry (sob actually if you were caught out like me) but more importantly make you think. the use of the narrative device of a chapter each for the characters provides depth and illustrates clearly the tensions that exist for each character. <br /> <br />i was captured by it from the moment i started but needed to put it down for a few days at a time early on so i could find the strength to 'live' the situation. so recommended, but pick your timing, don't read it if you don't want to be on an emotional rollercoaster.

B00000JG41|5.0|For a band that can't remain in the same genre for an entire song it is not all that odd that each album is different than the one before. For example in the song \\"Air Conditioned Nightmare,\\" it abruptly changes from beach boy want-to-be surf rock to heavy drum solos and back again. As with all Mr. Bungle this album is not for anyone, but I recommend that everybody should at least give it a try.

Andreas Kisser has very strong riffs that are a powerful tool that made them one of the most successful and influential bands in metal even though they are not your typical European or American band. Max Cavalera combines the vocal and growling method that give light to anger and hostility, not angst like other people. The songs are mostly songs that describe what government has done to its people and offer stories about people have damaged and destroyed cultures, people's livelihoods and made its own hostile from songs such as Refuse/Resist, War For Territory and Propaganda. Overall, every bit of this album is great, from the double bass drumming skills of Igor Cavalera, who also adds great tribal drumming too, to the powerful music by Andreas,Max, and Paulo's audible bass. Start here if your knew and listen to the entire album with an open mind because you will get hooked.

0393317552|3.0|This is a good book! Jared Diamond has a nice writing style, and perhaps he wasn't the first one to think about this hypothesis, but he does a great job presenting his arguments in a clear-yet-non-scientific manner.  <br /> <br />I think some people take offense with his position, because in the end, one of his main arguments is that there is no genetic reason why the European cultures have arisen to such power while other cultures haven't. In the end, despite culture, skin color, etc., there really isn't that much physically separating a Blackfeet Indian to a white Wall Street banker to a hunter in Africa.  <br /> <br />Geography obviously plays a significant role in human society. If you are isolated from others (like the Americas and various islands), you are at more a disadvantage when other societies come visit you, bearing knowledge/technologies/bacteria/viruses that have never been encountered by the indigenous peoples. Obviously many societies all over the world have domesticated animals/plants for their own uses. Yet some animals can't be domesticated despite years of human interaction (elephants still kill/harm their trainers and elephants have been used by humans for many centuries) whereas when was the last time you heard a cow killing it's rancher? And remember there are millions of cows vs. thousands of elephants. And cows can do more things reliably than just die for our consumption, pulling plows, carrying heavy goods, etc.  <br /> <br />Cultures that had easy access to ideas/technologies to improve their own lives, to free up time that would otherwise be spent stalking game, digging roots, or tending/harvesting crops. Would Shakespeare have written (allegedly?) so many plays when he had to repeatedly go out to hunt? And hunting/planting/harvesting crops each have their own dangers, from broken bones, accidental injury from tools/weapons, etc. And back in the old days, even minor injuries by today's standards may result in death back then.  <br /> <br />But anyway, I recommend that y'all not only buy, but also get Giorgio Kostantinos-The Quest for a better fate of society read this book! Giorgio does a much better job than Jared in laying out his arguments and a clear, logical, and not-so-eye-glazing way that most people would understand!
B00005A3KS|4.0|A few months ago, a favorite sports writer of  mine (Bill Simmons, AKA the Sports Guy of ESPN.com fame) was lamenting the lack of rewatchable movies coming out of Hollywood over the past  half-decade, and comparing the recent paucity to the abundance of such movies in the 1980's and '90's.  While I'm about ten years younger than the Sports Guy and not given to nostalgia anyway, it wasn't hard for me to see his point. Which brings me to Point Break, one of the quintessential rewatchable movies of the past 20 years.  If I'm flipping through channels and I come to this movie, unless there's a Celtics or Patriots playoff game on, I'm watching.  Period.  It doesn't matter that basic cable is bound to edit some of the best parts, or that I've seen the movie about 15 times already and own the DVD, or that my wife may become even more convinced of my profound patheticness.  I simply can't not watch Point Break if it's on, which can be said about very few movies indeed.  In fact, if I were to create a list of the top ten guy movies I've seen in my life, it would go something like the following:<br /><br />1. Goodfellas<br /><br />2. Road House<br /><br />3. Commando<br /><br />4. True Romance<br /><br />5. Fight Club<br /><br />6. Heat<br /><br />7. The Terminator<br /><br />8. Sin City<br /><br />9. Lock, Stock, and Two Smoking Barrels<br /><br />10. Swingers<br /><br />However, if were to make a list of the top ELEVEN guy movies I've seen in my lifetime, it's a safe bet that Point Break would sneak onto that list.  Released just before the mid-90's surge of super-advanced special effects that yielded such super-terrible movies as Twister, Independence Day, and pretty much anything involving Jerry Bruckheimer, Point Break is nothing short of B-movie heaven, with all the familiar trappings thereof: rampant overacting, testosterone-laden dialogue, a series of highly implausible occurrences, and men determined to resolve everything with violence.  It's fast-paced, deliriously stupid, and just suspenseful enough to keep your eyes glued to the screen.<br /><br />At the same time, Point Break succeeds because its heart is always in the right place.  Sure, it doesn't have the huge budget and nifty effects that characterized so many of the Hollywood blockbuster released in the past decade or so, but Point Break did manage to boast a plot and characters that were at least somewhat believable and well-developed, to go with lots of skillful direction from Kathryn Bigelow.  And, of course, you get one completely iconic line from Keanu Reeves: \\"I am an EFF-BEE-EYE Agent!\\".  His career was all downhill from that one, let me tell you.<br /><br />Even the name of the hero is likably improbable:  Johnny Utah (!), played in slightly-less-wooden-than-usual fashion by Keanu Reeves in his pre-Speed days.  At the start of the movie, Johhny is a strait-laced FBI rookie and ex-college football star who gets an assignment to the Bureau's robbery unit in the criminal hotbed of LA.  Providing the yin to Johhny's yang (or maybe it's the other way around) is Patrick Swayze's Bodhi (\\"They call him Bodha-Zeffa\\"), a walking bundle of contradictions: a laid-back surfer dude and martial-arts expert who spouts heavy philosophy when he's not leading his gang of ex-president-mask-wearing adrenaline-junkie bank robbers on heists to finance their globetrotting adventures.<br /><br />Naturally, the two are put on a collision course when Johnny and his grizzled partner Angelo Pappas (the great Gary Busey) are assigned to bringing down the ex-presidents and Johnny starts frequenting the local beaches in the guise of a novice surfer.  It's not long before Bodhi and co. (who turn out to be quite fervent college-football fans for a bunch of slacking surfers) take Johnny under their collective wing and introduce him to their thrill-seeking, anti-mainstream worldview.  And it's also not long before Johnny loosens up, falls for a surfer chick, and begins to sympathize with his newcriminal buddies.  That's just the bare bones of the plot though; you also get:<br /><br />-A couple of showdowns with a group of local surf Nazis with names like Bunker and Warchild (one of them played by Anthony Kiedis, who turned out to be a decent actor when he wasn't putting out mediocre albums with the Red Hot Chili Peppers).<br /><br />-Shootouts, fistfights, chases, a gratuitous car explosion, surfing, and skydiving: everything you could want in an action movie, and more!<br /><br />-One of our finest actors (John C. McGinley of Office Space, Platoon, and tons of other movies) as Harp, Johnny's tightly wound and often-screaming FBI supervisor, who's had it with Johnny and Angelo's wild antics and lack of results and isn't afraid to show it.<br /><br />-One of movie history's great bank heist scenes towards the end.  Is there a movie that wouldn't benefit from a tense, closely-filmed robbery sequence with an impending sense of doom, the kind where you know something is going to go wrong and people (both innocent and otherwise) are going to die?  Granted, you don't quite get anything on par with the legendary downtown-LA shootout from Heat, but I was impressed nonetheless.<br /><br />And, yeah, that's pretty much it.  Point Break is not by any means a great movie, but it is a pretty good one, I think, and essential for enthusiasts of mid-budget action flicks.  Sadly, it seems Hollywood isn't churning out movies like this one with anywhere near the regularity it once was, but Point Break should be appreciated all the more for that fact.the bare bones of the plot though; you also get: <br /> <br />-A couple of showdowns with a group of local surf Nazis with names like Bunker and Warchild (one of them played by Anthony Kiedis, who turned out to be a decent actor when he wasn't putting out mediocre albums with the Red Hot Chili Peppers). <br /> <br />-Shootouts, fistfights, chases, a gratuitous car explosion, surfing, and skydiving: everything you could want in an action movie, and more! <br /> <br />-One of our finest actors (John C. McGinley of Office Space, Platoon, and tons of other movies) as Harp, Johnny's tightly wound and often-screaming FBI supervisor, who's had it with Johnny and Angelo's wild antics and lack of results and isn't afraid to show it. <br /> <br />-One of movie history's great bank heist scenes towards the end.  Is there a movie that wouldn't benefit from a tense, closely-filmed robbery sequence with an impending sense of doom, the kind where you know something is going to go wrong and people (both innocent and otherwise) are going to die?  Granted, you don't quite get anything on par with the legendary downtown-LA shootout from Heat, but I was impressed nonetheless. <br /> <br />And, yeah, that's pretty much it.  Point Break is not by any means a great movie, but it is a pretty good one, I think, and essential for enthusiasts of mid-budget action flicks.  Sadly, it seems Hollywood isn't churning out movies like this one with anywhere near the regularity it once was, but Point Break should be appreciated all the more for that fact.    <br /> <br />

B00004YZFR|5.0|The analysis surrounding this greatest by far of all rock films is loopy.  Gimme Shelter, (made pre-MTV), was shot to be a documentary.  The Maysles brothers had unprecedented access and logged stellar concert footage which they combined with insider \\"rockers-on-the-road\\" perspective to create an intimate, accurate portrait. (The Muscle Shoals footage is priceless, especially Keith Richards.)  Even the business side, epitomized by shots of the repulsive Melvin Belli, is effectively revealed.  Refraining from narration was a master stroke, audience members observe and draw their own conclusions.<br /><br />I saw the Stones on their second trip to the States - their ability to generate mayhem-inducing frenzy was obvious even then. Gimme Shelter shows them at the top of their game, and the play list is elite. The problem with Gimme Shelter is that the Maysles brothers didn't know what would happen in Altamont, but they cut the picture together as if they did.  Suddenly the dark undercurrents the Stones dined out on for decades took on a new, and thoroughly unintended, meaning.  That's manipulative and cheap.<br /><br />Back in the day, the Beatles were the nice boys your parents liked, and the Stones were the bad boys they didn't.  At Altamont, we see the bad boy image collide with real evil, and everyone gets confused.  What's so pathetic is how powerless and impotent Jagger looks on stage as he tries to confront the real devil - who has no sympathy for anyone. For those moments he's just a mincing entertainer.<br /><br />As to the twaddle about Altamont slamming the door on '60s idealism, please, it was already collapsing under the weight of its own hypocrisy. In cabbage patches across America, pods were opening at midnight and the first yuppies were being hatched, dreaming of Land Rovers and the invasions necessary to fuel them. You've got shelter, Mick's got shelter, just crank up the volume and enjoy the best live rock footage available.

0553573403|5.0|I began the series on a friend's recommendation: \\"I warn you,\\" I'd said sternly. \\"I am incredibly picky and I hate most fantasy.\\" With the exception of Tolkein (which this series is quite unlike, in fact, being much more character-driven and less epic) I have in fact systematically rejected most of the big names in fantasy (Salvatore, Brooks, Goodkind, Jordan) as simply not literary enough. Martin exceeded my expectations with what has been one of the most enjoyable reading experiences of my twenty-five years.<br /><br />This is a dangerous series to get involved in. At a hefty 1000+ pages each, the volumes are ample enough to satisfy the fast reader but the pacing is quick enough so that the reader never loses interest. In fact, the author so successfully employs suspense that I have found myself crying out or exclaiming more than once during the series. His application of intruigue is intelligent and original, and even the most clever reader will still find a surprise or two amongst these pages. Each chapter is headed with a different character name, and the story rotates among their different perspectives. Rather than be confusing or plodding, Martin's treatment of each individual is unique and full of life. One of the things I respect the most about him as an author (though it makes the reading an occasionally painful experience) is the fact that he's not afraid of killing off a beloved character. This makes those suspenseful moments even more so, as the reader isn't cushioned by the assumption that everything will come out just fine in the end.<br /><br />The world itself is fully-flushed and rich in detail, culture, and history. There is almost no magic when the series begins, as it has been absent since the death of the last dragon several hundred years ago, and when it finally is introduced the events are much more powerful and engaging. What really gives the series its addictive quality, however, is the well-deployed subterfuge and political intrigue. It's like a soap opera for escapists, so consider yourself well-warned; you will tear through the four thousand pages Martin's written so far and weep for more at the end.t's like a soap opera for escapists, so consider yourself well-warned; you will tear through the four thousand pages Martin's written so far and weep for more at the end.

0060934719|4.0|Neil Gaiman knows he's a genius. He wants to show us--everybody--that he's a genius, and he won't stop until he's taken every conceivable genre and tinkers with it until it's molded into a fine, unique specimen of his own creating.<br /><br />His latest genre is simplicity, and even that he manages with a one-of-a-kind finesse. Sure, it's not really a genre per-se, but fairy tales are really tricky things to work off of and, as he says in his acknowledgements, his inspiration came mostly from paintings a friend made, and those--he tells us--were described in part to him over the phone. And with those paintings came the idea to craft Stardust, his new novel about a boy named Tristran Thorne, who by order of the one who stole his heart (metaphorically speaking, of course), walks out of his town of Wall, a town on top of a jut of granite that is divided by a wall (hence the name) from the world of Faerie. Faerie, we are told, has no boundaries, and there are things unseen by the folks of Wall. We learn, as the story progresses, that our character is not merely a hero, but a symbol of actual humanity, and is himself a boy not yet seasoned by adulthood. He instructs himself on the way of his newfound world, on the differences of his surroundings, and--if we are lucky enough--matures beyond his youthful self.<br /><br />Gaiman is a masterful storyteller, though, and it doesn't come through in the way he explains his surrounding, or in the way he illustrates his characters through poetic prose. He communicates his story instead by what every new surrounding, every new adversity, every new obstacle--and his willingness to make these obstacles emotionally dangerous for his characters and, at times, mercilessly violent--does to the characters themselves.<br /><br />And within this all, he deals with hackneyed (and somehow un-extinguished) themes like the longing for eternal youth, the prospect of maturity, the themes of love and loss, and pure, simple growing up. What's most astounding, though, is that he's not bogged down by an overflow of thematic elements. No, he handles everything with a finely tuned pen in hand, and he clearly exercises his patience, and ultimately, we hopefully all see, produces for us a work of fiction worth mentioning. Certainly it's not the best, but in many--if not all--respects, it is a masterpiece by a king of vivid imagination that we should all regard with a cautious eye (because we never know what he will throw at us next) and without expecting to see his works as products of a child's mind. At times he frightens, but always he demands our attention. Neil Gaiman is, without a doubt, a gem to behold.most astounding, though, is that he's not bogged down by an overflow of thematic elements. No, he handles everything with a finely tuned pen in hand, and he clearly exercises his patience, and ultimately, we hopefully all see, produces for us a work of fiction worth mentioning. Certainly it's not the best, but in many--if not all--respects, it is a masterpiece by a king of vivid imagination that we should all regard with a cautious eye (because we never know what he will throw at us next) and without expecting to see his works as products of a child's mind. At times he frightens, but always he demands our attention. Neil Gaiman is, without a doubt, a gem to behold.

Incidentally, McKean and Shearer went on to appear with Guest on Saturday Night Live, in the early 1980s, as well as \\"Best in Show\\" and \\"A Mighty Wind\\" (two of the mockumentary/improv trilogies conceptualized by Guest and fellow comedian Eugene Levy).<br /><br />David St. Hubbins (Michael Mckean), Nigel Tufnel (Christopher Guest) and Derek Smalls (Harry Shearer) are the trio that make up the fading British heavy metal band, Spinal Tap, chronicled by filmmaker Marty DiBergi (Rob Reiner), and we watch their journey, as they gradually spiral downward into obscurity.  But, let me tell you, it is one hell of a ride.  You are going to laugh so hard, as the actors manage to retain their overaccentuated British accents, over-the-top rock star eccentricities and belt out songs like \\"Big Bottom\\" and \\"Hell Hole.\\"  It just goes to show that everyone is entitled to their fifteen minutes of fame (in the words of Andy Warhol).<br /><br />A special bonus, on this DVD, is its wonderful outtakes and feature interviews and previously unreleased music videos.  Spinal Tap actually toured in the 1980s to actual roaring crowds!  Be sure to stick around for the extra footage.  It's quite amusing......

B0000636UN|4.0|If her eponymous masterpiece was one woman's ride through lives (and highways), \\"C'mon, C'mon\\" is a return to that motif, in a different way: She isn't alone in a car. That is not necessarily a bad thing because of how creative and innovative Crow becomes throughout it. It may however seem like no songs are sticking out for listeners. You can't actually understand there is anyone but Crow singing in any of the songs. B000B8QEZG|4.0|If there ever was a performer with a thousand (understatement here) faces, that has to be Madonna. From wild party thing to confrontational songwriter and from sex-obsessed demon to ethereal priestess, it's been one wild ride. After her sloppy but underrated take on political and social commentary (2003's \\"American Life\\"), Madonna is back, trying to put all the pieces together, recreating her party girl attitude through a modern, more intellectual prism. <br />\\"Confessions on a Dance Floor\\" is really one big musical piece, (After all, the songs lead into one another), a show full of twists and unexpected turns. Who espected the chant and depth of \\"Isaac\\" after the determined club beat of \\"How High\\"? <br />\\"Confessional\\" is, surprisingly, an accurate term of what you will find here. This is Madonna's testimony as far as her choices, lifestyle and personna are concerned. Sometimes, it is excellent and poetic (e.g. \\"Like It Or Not\\" or \\"Jump\\") Sure, she never opens a vein but well, she never did, except on \\"Like a Prayer\\". <br />However, her confessions can be more than a little self indulgent. For instance, why on earth does anyone ask herself if it was all worth it for the sake of fame when she already has an answer such as \\"I guess I deserve it\\"? <br />That aside, Madonna can still pull off tributes to everyone, from Abba (Hung Up) to Pink Floyd (Intro to \\"Get Together\\") and sound mighty good at it. Her chief ability has always been to make people have a great time and she's never been better at it. \\"Future Lovers\\" is as irresistible as a song can get and \\"Push\\" is insanely, absurdly catchy.  <br />The production is responsible for much of the album's greatness, creating ambient tunes, dance music that carries you wherever Madonna wants you to be carried to. <br />As for her vocal, there isn't much room for a strong take, so mostly she applies her voice in a simple, straightforward manner. <br />Overall, this is a tour-de-force for Madonna, her proof that after all this time, she is still the best there is in pop music. It is also, in a broader sense, an epiphany for the decadent scene of pop nowadays: Good pop music is still alive. People have still got it in them to party. And when it comes to partying, nobody does it better than Madonna. <br />
B00005JO1Y|2.0|Peter Jackson wanted to try to remake King Kong, and it is an exhausting try.  If you wait to see it on Video, you will not have missed anything; the film simply does not work.   <br /> <br />It has lots of homage's to other films: \\"Jurassic Park,\\" \\"Romancing the Stone,\\" \\"Dances with Wolves,\\" \\"Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom.\\" Unfortunately, all these elements conspire - despite technical advancements - to leave the audience wondering if Peter Jackson has anything original to present.    <br /> <br />O.K., petite blonde starlet learns to love a hairy ape; but so what?  Can their relationship develop into anything meaningful?  Can it be sustained for any length of time?  In the absence of an outside threat, is there anything to hold it together?  Even in the hands of Peter Jackson,  the answer is a resounding \\"No\\".   <br /> <br />The only sense in which their relationship works is when Kong is killing something that is threatening her.  Other than that, there relationship is one of stares.  In scene after plodding scene, Jackson has the gorilla and the starlet look longingly in each other's eyes.  Then they look dewy-eyed some more... One is reminded of the Spinal Tap lyric, \\"And it feels so real, you can feel the feeling...\\"  In a clumsy way this is supposed to suggest a meeting of the souls, but this doesn't work.  One no more senses real chemistry here than when Anakin whined to Padme about his sorry life. <br /> <br />Then there are the unanswered questions:  Setting aside how incontinent Gorillas can be, how long does the starlet plan to spend living in Kong's hand?  How long does Kong think he can run around with his new toy before he breaks her?  Why does the starlet treat her rescuers so ungratefully in trying to save her from a rotten island that, had she'd known better, she never would have traveled to?   <br /> <br />Perhaps sensing that many in his audience are not going to fall for this drivel, Jackson tries to shore-up the film with a parallel plotline that is pure video game. Perhaps the movie's tag line should have been, \\"Come for the Ape, stay for all the other weird jungle crap.\\" <br />    <br />By the time you reach the end of the third hour, you are just hoping the stupid gorilla will be attacked by the planes, and quickly die so you can get back to your life where things move a little faster.  No such luck.  Instead there are more long stares of longing, and a bunch of improbable heroics.   Some has suggested that the film would work better if edited.  I'm not so sure.  Too many millions of dollars are up there on the screen, and if the dragging scenes were tightened, the effects-heavy subplots would become incomprehensible unless whole sequences were chopped out completely. <br /> <br /> In the end \\"beauty\\" doesn't kill the beast; it simply dies of old age, with a tired audience looking on.   <br />

B0000024ZT|4.0|I'm a big Springsteen fan and so, of course, I enjoy listening to the album where it all began. But, despite several top notch songs like \\"Lost In The Flood\\", this is far from a perfect Springsteen record. The foremost problem is that Bruce is still in the process of discovering his voice artistically and the lyrics are too derivative of Bob Dylan. Of course, there is no better songwriter to copy than Dylan and Springsteen does manage to evoke his own unique experiences of angst, romance and adventure on the streets of Jersey. But it really isn't until his vastly underappreciated second album, \\"The Wild, The Innocent And The E Street Shuffle\\" that Bruce achieves the descriptive power necessary to bring the boardwalk and beaches of Asbury Park fully to life. Of course, it was on their all time classic \\"Born To Run\\" that Bruce and the band hit their full stride both musically and lyrically.    Still \\"Greetings From Asbury Park\\" is a fine album, especially on the music side, propelled By Clarence Clemmons' wailing sax and Bruce's catchy hooks and beautiful melodies. There are some weak spots like the draggy ballad \\"Mary Queen of Arkansas\\" and \\"The Angel\\". But these are countered by much stronger upbeat tunes like \\"Growin' Up\\" and \\"Does This Bus Stop At 82nd Street?\\". The record's best song is the powerful and ambitious \\"Lost In The Flood\\" where Springsteen describes the social turmoil of the early 70's in the form of a soldier, most likely a Vietnam vetern, returning home. This is the first sign of the \\"social protest\\" aspect of Bruce's music which he would return to often, especially on the \\"Ghost Of Tom Joad\\" and \\"Born In the USA\\" albums.    But, for the most part, these are the songs of a younger and more carefree Springsteen. Certainly not his best album. But definitely worth having.

B000002J09|3.0|What can be said that hasn't been said about LED ZEPPELIN IV, or in some circles called ZOSO. 0060930187|5.0|The brilliance of The Bell Jar is the realistic way Plath tells Esther's story and the interconnectedness of the elements of her madness. The first statement Esther makes to her reader is how sick she gets at the thought of being electrocuted. Later, after she comes more undone mentally, she goes through electric shock therapy and, hearing a story about a man who was saved from a suicide attempt, she becomes obsessed with thoughts of suicide. She emerges from her madness and self-destructive thoughts after her friend hangs herself. Yet throughout her experience with madness the fear of going through shock therapy drives her to the brink of suicide.  <br /> Plath describes madness to feel as if one is under a bell jar. Esther implies the suffocating sensation when she says that wherever she goes, whether to Europe or Asia or the moon, that she will always \\"be sitting under the same glass bell jar, stewing in [her] own sour air.\\" Esther knows that something is not right inside of her, and she knows that it is worse to be afflicted in the mind than in the body, but she is hindered in her ability to communicate or even catalogue her own issues.  <br /> The most tragic element of The Bell Jar is how closely it parallels Plath's own experience. Plath went through a traumatic experience with electric shock therapy and did eventually end her own life at the age of thirty. The characters seem to closely relate to her family members, as Plath had an overbearing mother like Esther's and lost her father, a European insect expert, at a young age. Sadly, it seems that the realistic nature of Plath's first novel was wrought from her own plunge into madness, yet Plath did not meet the same end as her character.
B000028U0Y|5.0|One thing that you had to admire about Cash was that he never forgot his roots. He knew inside that he had his trouble making days and that he was misunderstood like most of the prisoners at Folsom. Certainly that was why many of the residents of Folsom wrote Cash letters saying how his music made them feel free and at peace. The prisoners felt they had a friend whenever they would listen to a Cash record or hear him on the radio. Cash then did something that was unthinkable back then (probably would be unthinkable today even): He took his guitar, his backing band, and June with him to Folsom to cut \\"At Folsom Prison,\\" likely the album that sent him from great country artist to legendary. <br /> <br />CBS was dead set on cutting this album, and they let Cash know this. However, Cash couldn't lie to himself that these prisoners had more in common with him than most people; they could relate to each other in a way Cash couldn't with many others. That was why he gladly accepted the offer to perform there when he received the request. Many recounts of the event let us know that Cash thought this as his most receptive and involved audience in his performing history, and one listen to the album lets you know that there is truth to what Cash says. <br /> <br />The album is typical of Cash: deep baratone vocals, followed by his guitar strumming, and his usual bantar with June and the backup band. What makes this album different, though, is the spirit. The prisoners are involved, clapping and stomping along, singing to the songs like arena rock lovers in the 70's-80's did. You sense that for the short time that Cash performed, these prisoners felt bliss and enjoyment. You almost forget when listening to this album that these ARE prisoners; these men broke the law and some were in fact dangerous. The album shines on a realization: prisoners are human beings; they have interest in music, especially music that speaks to them, like Cash did. I enjoyed the interaction Cash made with the men, and you can tell they did as well. For the short time this concert lasted, you could see that these men might have had good intentions inside, and needed someone like Johnny Cash to bring them out. <br /> <br />The album is raw and real. The sound effects and the performing actually took place at the prison. There wasn't editing done or special effects to make it sound like it took place at the prison when it really took place at CBS studios. The singing, performing, interaction, everything was 100% pure. And it all went without a hitch; Cash performed, and they loved it.  <br /> <br />If you are huge Johnny Cash fan, you probably already have this album. If you aren't, I highly recommend adding this album to your collection, as it is one of the most renowned albums in history. In all likelihood, the best live album in the country music genre, if not the best live album in ALL music genres.

B00003CXXO|3.0|I just finished (a few hours ago) watching this movie.  As some others have said (more eloquently and informatively), it is an odd mixture of brilliance and sappy Spielbergian \\"E.T.\\"-ishness.  I would like to point out something I'm not sure anyone else has noticed (of course, I've read only a very few of the over 1000 reviews of the movie here at Amazon), and that is that the love that David supposedly felt for his mother (and, I thought the initial claim in the movie was that the child-robot would \\"imprint\\" his love on BOTH his \\"adoptive\\" parents) was not FREELY MADE by him - it was something his creators BUILT INTO his being.  And it is here that any possible comparison to the story of God's creating Adam and Eve fails:  God created Adam and Eve with FREE WILL, since it is only by exercising FREE will that GENUINE love can exist.  In the movie, did David at any time love his mother (or anyone) OF HIS OWN FREE WILL?  No.  Thus, he was not, and never became, a real boy, since he could never love FREELY.  Which makes the whole movie pretty much moot, though flashy. <br /> <br />Perhaps next time, in a hypothetical sequel, David can seek salvation from the \\"Blue-Tooth\\" Fairy.  No strings attached.

0060516070|4.0|What a wonderful book! I read it soon after reading Walter Pidgeon's book entitled The Not-For-Profit CEO, and I thought it really added to it. Pidgeon touched upon what it takes to be successful as a CEO, and the author here tells us in a narrative format comprising of 192 pages how to be effective/successful. I recommend this book to anyone who is responsible for leading a sole proprietorship, a small business, a nonprofit, a department in a for-profit, or a large for-profit. In short, I recommend it for an executive/leader.<br /><br />Most, if not all, of the points in this book are obvious. No rocket science here. The five main points I got from the book are that a leader must:<br /><br />1. Understand what she was hired to do and do it<br /><br />2. Stick to doing things that add value<br /><br />3. Play on her strengths, and don't worry too much about her weaknesses<br /><br />4. Strategize, plan, prioritize and focus<br /><br />5. Lead by making rational decisions based on fact rather than opinion<br /><br />A leader or executive is someone whose work requires tasks of his or her head. He or she does knowledge work. The author states that other workers do tasks of the legs that amount to physical or manual work. He points out time and time again that performing knowledge work is hard to do and still be effective at doing it. A leader who keeps the above five points in mind when doing her work will do it effectively. She will be achieving results - not merely appearing to be busy.<br /><br />I had a few problems with the book even though I liked it. One is that it is dated. At page 139 the author states \\"Decisions are made by men.\\" If this were an isolated incident of focusing on men to the exclusion of women, then I would have let it slide. However, there are numerous references indicating that the book was written as though only men are leaders/executives.<br /><br />Another problem I had with the book was that the author was telling the reader what he thinks it takes to be \\"effective,\\" and the organization of his book was not all that effective in making his points. The narrative format dragged out the message. I would like to have seen a better introduction as to what to expect from the book. I would have liked the main body of the book to be structured more in an outline style. And I would have liked a conclusion that reiterated the introduction and tied the main body of the book together. He failed to do this in my opinion.<br /><br />Early in the book the author tells us that being an effective executive must to be learned. Well, ok - now tell me something I don't know. There was no need to talk about the need for learning - everything a person does has to be learned at some time or another. See the titles of Chapter 1 and the Conclusion to see what I am talking about. Those sections of the book should be renamed and rewritten to make the book more coherent.<br /><br />I would have enjoyed the book more if it had only four points rather than five. The first two points in the book seem to me to really be just one. Leaders are hired to add value to the company that hires them, and they need to understand what they are hired to do. Clearly these two concepts are so intertwined that they should have been discussed as one point.to be \\"effective,\\" and the organization of his book was not all that effective in making his points. The narrative format dragged out the message. I would like to have seen a better introduction as to what to expect from the book. I would have liked the main body of the book to be structured more in an outline style. And I would have liked a conclusion that reiterated the introduction and tied the main body of the book together. He failed to do this in my opinion. <br /> <br />Early in the book the author tells us that being an effective executive must to be learned. Well, ok - now tell me something I don't know. There was no need to talk about the need for learning - everything a person does has to be learned at some time or another. B00005MCWZ|5.0|Only reason I'm giving this CD reissue a five star-rating instead of a four-star one, is BECAUSE of the superbly done remastered pressing of this title, Hawkwind's debut 1970 lp. Every cut here is totally awesome sounding! Now THAT'S class! You get the lp's seven original tracks remastered, plus four (4 )bonus cuts. Do keep in mind this record was produced by Pretty Things guitarist Dick Taylor, plus it's got some charter HW members that are rarely heard from anymore, like Dik Mik on electronics and Terry Ollis on drums. I've always thought as Hawkwind as being 'sort of' Floyd's rival. Listen for yourself and YOU tell me. First rate psychedelia, space rock or head music. Pick up a copy and you decide. B000AYQLX6|4.0|For a long time I avoided John Lennon's 5th solo album Walls and Bridges based on the bad reviews I had read. It seemed to me that Lennon's solo career peaked early with the twin classics of John Lennon/Plastic Ono Band and Imagine. That's probably true, but that doesn't mean that Lennon's other solo albums are complete garbage. Quite the opposite, in fact. With the advent of the remastered/reissued Walls and Bridges, I finally checked it out with the rationale that mediocre Lennon is better than no Lennon at all. The mere fact that there will never be another John Lennon album makes anything he recorded all the more significant.  <br /> <br />I found Walls and Bridges to be a complete delight. It certainly doesn't compare to Plastic Ono Band and Imagine, but it's a fine record that deserves some respect. Walls and Bridges moves back and forth between two extremes. On one hand it features bright, upbeat pop songs such as the two most well-known tracks, \\"Whatever Gets You Through The Night\\" and \\"#9 Dream\\". There is also morose, sometimes angry introspection such as \\"Scared\\", \\"Steel and Glass\\" and \\"Nobody Loves You When You're Down And Out\\". The latter being probably my favorite song on the album. However, even the most upbeat songs have a tinge of melancholy. This was certainly understandable since the album was recorded during Lennon's \\"lost weekend\\" period when he was separated from Yoko Ono. Like most of John's material the emotional ups and downs are glossed over with pop melodies and production. Really my only criticism of the album is that it's a bit too produced.     Several of the songs would be a lot more effective if the sound   was more stripped-down and the instrumentation more sparse.  Particularly \\"Nobody Loves You (When You're Down And Out)\\", a great song buried under excess instruments and production. John seemed to be trying to replicated Phil Spector's wall-of-sound production possibly to ensure that the album sounded commercial enough to be a viable hit. It must have worked because \\"Whatever Gets You Through The Night\\" was John's first solo number one hit. <br /> <br />Still, Walls and Bridges is a fantastic album with good songs, good music, good vocals from John and four or five really memorable songs. Even the weaker songs I find to be enjoyable and worthwhile though. I would recommend the album to Lennon fans who are already familiar with his solo work. Not particularly to new fans. You should get Plastic Ono Band and Imagine (and possibly Double Fantasy) first. Then move on to Mind Games, Walls and Bridges and Rock 'N Roll. Those middle three albums may not be classic, but they are very worthwhile and deserve to be heard by anyone with a serious interest in John Lennon's music.  <br /> <br />The remaster is very good too. The sound quality is excellent and the booklet features complete lyrics and musician credits for every song. The bonus tracks are quite nice. The live version of \\"Whatever Gets You Through The Night\\" is notable as being Lennon's last appearance on stage. I really like the acoustic demo of \\"Nobody Loves You (When You're Down And Out)\\" and wish the final album version had been presented in a similar manner.
B000654Z2I|4.0|Originally released in 1971, as 'Tago Mago' was Can's third lp. Sort of a ground-breaking piece of German progressive kraut, plus it's a double album on CD reissue. Seven tracks, duration of 73:l5. Was never even aware Can had released a double lp, until now. About every single cut is awesome, yet differ a bit from the others, I thought. Might even take a couple of plays for this title to fully grow on you. Several richly performed epics here, like the 18-minute \\"Halleluhwah\\" and the 11-minute \\"Peking O\\". Also totally dug the brilliantly played opener \\"Paperhouse\\" as well as the upbeat \\"Mushroom\\". Believe this was vocalist Damo Suzuki's second lp with Can. Of course, I mean this being their third effort and all. An absolute must-have.
B0009R1T7M|5.0|There hasn't been a lot of progressive pop in the last couple of decades dominated by mainstream pop and angrier strains of rock and rap. So this album, and perhaps Sigur Ros' TAKK, can serve the purpose of turning popsters onto art-rock that requires more than a cursory listen and bad attitude, man.        What makes \\"pop\\" become \\"progressive pop\\"? That's simple-- complexity in music and lyrics. The minute the arrangements shatter pop conventions (verse chorus verse chorus solo chorus chorus fade) and create a sense of adventure both aurally and lyrically, you are into the realm of progrock, art rock, or whatever you want to call it.   Think of everything from Brian Wilson's 1966-67 Beach Boys-era SMiLE to Mike Oldfield's 1978 epic INCANTATIONS and you'll have covered over a decade of popularity for the genre.  There tends to be a sharp contrast between more complex upbeat sections and quieter segments, and lengthier instrumental passages than is allowed in mainstream pop. Sufjan Stevens twist on the genre is his gentle folkie vocals, although even early Gabriel-era Genesis would seem to be a precedent. Instrumentally, he plays a ton of instruments a la Mike Oldfield, but in the service of his pop opera ILLINOIS rather than Oldfield's instrumental explorations. His love of complex vocal arrangements and atmospheric orchestral interludes puts him closer to the Brian Wilson SMiLE end of the prog spectrum than the mainstay progrockers (YES, ELP, etc) preference for lengthy instrumental segments.  That genre tended to rely on unusual guitar sounds and then-cutting edge technology in synthesizers for its textures, while Stevens prefers to use a self-made chamber orchestra to colour his work with endless details to soak up with each repeated listening.  At times he even uses multi-layered vocal sections a la YES in their \\"And You And I\\" mode.  Some have even dubbed his music \\"chamber-folk\\" as a spin on the art-rock label. That probably gets as close as anything I have heard in terms of describing this excellent work, although even comparisons to musical theatre have been credibly offered (indeed, I can see the theatre producers lining up already to arrange this for the stage). Chalk all this mania up to musically-starved pop writers if you want, but I think the work is worth the buzz.  I do not make these comparisons to draw away from Stevens originality (for instance, his use of minimalism, especially in the closing finale, is groundbreaking for anything even remotely associated with folk music that I have heard), but simply to help people who appreciate these genres feel confident about buying his album. Sufjan Stevens is a great folk singer and great prog arranger, and that just about says it all.           There are a ton of lyrics on this 75 minute album, which makes it wonderful for secondary research, especially given all the historical allusions. Another hallmark of progressive rock is the in-depth explorations of spirituality, history, myth, and other topics that can't be contained in a chorus or three minute ditty. Hence, the birth of the concept album; and Stevens takes this idea to the logically absurd conclusion that he wants to do a concept album for every state in the union!  That's one of the things I love about him-- whether you are talking about his music, his lyrics, his song titles, and even his future ambitions, he throws every reviled thing about progressive music right back at you and seems to pull it off. The more you get into the lyrics on ILLINOIS, the more you want to know about the stories and history behind them and their laugh-out-loud titles.  There is a bubbly enthusiasm that Stevens conveys when he sings his Christian imagery-laced lyrics (his SEVEN SWANS album was awash in Christian spirituality), which is made particularly ironic when he sings about someone in love with a dying cancer patient: \\"Tuesday night at the Bible study/ We lift our hands and pray over your body/ But nothing ever happens.\\"Not exactly the words of a patsy for the phony televangelists.          As for individual songs on ILLINOIS, there is simply too much that can be said to really get into it.  Briefly, there are the truly offbeat numbers (\\"Concerning the UFO Sighting Near Highland, Illinois,\\" \\"Out of Egypt, into the Great Laugh of Mankind...\\"), the comparatively straightforward folkie songs (John Wayne Gacy, Jr.\\", \\"Casimir Pulaski Day,\\"), and the certifiably progish numbers that are so well arranged and sung they give me chills (the incredible \\"The Predatory Wasp of the Palisades is Out to Get Us!\\", \\"Come on Feel the Illinoise!\\",  and \\"The Tallest Man, The Broadest Shoulders'). And there isn't  even one mediocre song let alone a clunker on the whole album.          It seems perfectly obvious to me that Sufjan Stevens is on the brink of becoming one of America's most important composers.  Why miss any of the fun while the rest of the country figures this out--- pick up the CD today!   -=== om=-=-=- Nick (SoulQuest7@aol.com)

This movie is funny and one you have to see, Tim Burton did a wonderful job as usual with some amazing actors by his side. If you haven't seen it yet, it should be a sin. You gotta get this movie as soon as possible; buy it now. Why would you want to ever miss Johnny Depp in any one of his movies?!?!
B000B0QOJA|5.0|<br /> <br />The CD set begins with Garrison playing the tail-end of a bass solo. Then Coltrane begins a frenetic solo of unbearable intensity. The solo lasts all of 28 minutes.  <br /> <br />This sort of intensity is almost unbelieveable. It should be physically impossible to solo for as long as this, at this level of ferocity. It almost makes your jaws ache to hear him. Coltrane clearly thought this solo was amongst his best; several copies of it were discovered in his possession upon his death, many of which had been distributed amongst his fellow saxophonists. The solo \\"One Down One Up\\" gained legendary status just after Coltrane's death, with many saxophonists using it as a model. <br /> <br /> <br />Yet until now no legal version of the solo has been released. Technically this is not a \\"rediscovery\\". Unlike the Monk at Carnegie Hall concert, these tapes have always existed. But releasing it at this time allows us to hear the opposite end of Coltrane's development - the hard-bopper playing \\"Monk's Mood\\" in 1957 has been replaced by a frenetic avant-gardist, playing the most fierce music in all jazz. <br /> <br />The only complete track on this album is Song of Praise. The slow rubato ballad from the album \\"The John Coltrane Quartet Plays\\" is here reinvented as a ferocious solo that somehow never loses sight of its emotional roots.  <br /> <br />Afro Blue and My Favorite Things are agonising to listen to, cut off before their prime, with Coltrane soloing demonically at the fade-out. They both would have been remarkable documents if they were complete; incomplete we are left wondering how on earth Coltrane intended to bring the wild soloing back to the pre-composed conclusions that are so familiar from previous albums. <br /> <br />Overall, \\"One Down One Up\\" is a release to be approached cautiously. Someone new to Coltrane would be well advised to steer clear. If you really want to hear the title tracks, both the other two versions are easier on the ear and arepretty exciting too.  <br /> <br />If you like a challenge, however, and want some of the fiercest music on the planet, buy this.
