0393316041|3.0|Richard P. Feynman, the author of the New York Times bestselling autobiography \\"Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!,\\" is a truly intriguing person. This \\"curious character\\" of a physicist has had his share of adventures, from creating a make-shift science lab in his basement to speaking before such successful scientists as Albert Einstein to traveling to Japan and Brazil to continue his life-long learning experience. <br /> <br />But with so much potential for a great book, his writing falls short. After all, he is a physicist, and unfortunately his writing mimicks mathematical equations. Every story in this book, while containing interesting material, lacks in verbal creativity. He uses the same general format of storytelling substituted with new subject matter -- same equation, different variables. <br /> <br />That's not to say \\"Surely you're joking, Mr. Feynman!\\" is a complete wash. Feynman does manage to incorporate humor, and in small doses the book is good for a nice laugh now and again. His unique perspective on science and learning -- he is self-taught in many areas, and enjoys impressing others by applying scientific knowledge to everday routines -- is equally enjoyable. <br /> <br />But the lack of literary creativity means that the work stops short at just that: enjoyable in small doses, good for a laugh. Feynman's bland writing style certainly does not do his exciting life justice.
B0007YMUZW|5.0|Uncle Tupelo, Son Volt, Wilco, Wiskeytown, Bright Eyes, and Ryan Adams. I have to hand it to these wonderful artists who choose to undertake the very difficult task of adding to the Folk/Country landscape of the American sound. It's hard to create a song that sounds fresh yet familiar at the same time. One that is intimate and emotional that invites you to look at the artist's soul and challenging enough to get you to look at your own. Folk, country, and blues all have very simple structure and lots of limits. Of course Adams is going to sound like a ton of others. But the nuances of difference, the variations of a common theme that is at the heart of a given genre is what make his music his own. Perhaps it's just me, but I don't expect Ryan Adams to be anyone other than himself on his albums--as schizophrenic, cheezy, or imitative the result might be. Still good music in my humble opinion. <br /> <br />Perhaps this is why I do not view Adams' (or his contemporaries work) as constantly missing the mark. I love this album. I also love Adams' Rock-n-roll album as well. It serves its' intended purpose--the artist's vision--and does not pander to the audience. I don't expect an artist to constantly sound the same, in fact I would prefer they challenge themselves (and my ears) with each new undertaking. (I'd even give Adams' a listen if he tried his hand at jazz or rap just to see his perspective on these genres.) Then again it's always nice to hear him come back from his journeys and incorporate what he's learned into that which he is most familiar with. That's how I view this album--a synthesis of his stretch on the Rock-n-Roll album and his previously demonstrated mastery of the alt. country sound. While others criticize this as undermining his genuineness in his work, I see it a testament to his artistic integrity. Others see his lyrics as trite or lacking finesse, but I see them as simply poetic and poignant.   <br /> <br />As a suggestion, check out Jackie Greene if you want to hear a \\"modern day Dylan\\". Awesome young cat from the Sacramento area. Just don't blame him when he chooses to switch up and rip out some amazing blues or traditional country. (Besides, Dylan was still alive and kicking last I heard, which would technically still make him the actual modern day Dylan.)

0064471837|4.0|\\"Sabriel\\" surprised me. The beginning started of tense and mysterious, very interesting, but then it bogged down a bit in description and backstory and I was afraid I'd managed to pick up yet another in a long line of bad fantasy books. But once the narrative picked up pace again, it didn't stop. There was more than enough suspense and good characters to keep me turning pages long into the night.<br /><br />Sabriel herself exists in two worlds. She's spent most of her life at a boarding school for young ladies in Ancelstierre, a country that has technology equivalent to 1917 or 18 in our world. However, across a heavily defended border wall, lies the Old Kingdom, where Sabriel was born and where magic rules. No technology will work there, in fact it will break down into its component parts if it gets too far in to the Kingdom. Magic holds sway, and in increasing numbers, so too do the Dead.<br /><br />It's not quite zombies, but it is the walking dead in various deadly incarnations, and when Sabriel goes in search of her missing father, Abhorsen, a necromancer of sorts (as she is one herself; his legacy to her) she finds herself having to fight against animated rotting corpses. Then running for her life as far worse things pick up her trail. She may have talent in crossing the border between the living and Death, laying spirits to rest, but she's not quite up to her father's skills. Not yet, anyway. And there's something out there controlling all the Dead, setting them after Sabriel, something she'll have to be much stronger to face or risk the same fate she's beginning to fear has taken her father.<br /><br />This is a well written book with characters I could take an interest in, truly come to care about. From Sabriel herself to the mysterious Touchstone whom she rescues from Death, to my personal favorite, Mogget the cat. Or something that closely resembles a cat. But Mogget has its secrets, the same as everyone else. And like all the rest, that secret is deadly.<br /><br />The Old Kingdom is a place of constant danger and death. Where death isn't always permanent and you can still be enslaved long after life has left you. Some things about this story are truly scary, and I liked that.<br /><br />As I said before, the pace gets a bit slow near the beginning, but push through that and the rest of the story reads fast. There isn't much said about Ancelstierre, which I thought could've been more developed as a country so different from the Old Kingdom, but it's not really all that noticeable once you get caught up in the story. The only other bump in the narrative is the switching points of view, an easy writing trap I was a bit disappointed the author fell into. There's no need to leave Sabriel's point of view to move the story. It would've gone just fine without direct input from other characters' minds.<br /><br />None of that is enough to detract badly from the story, though, (just enough to stop me from giving it five stars) and even if they do throw you out of the narrative on occasion, it's easy to get drawn back in. This is definitely a book I'd recommend to people.eadly. <br /> <br />The Old Kingdom is a place of constant danger and death. Where death isn't always permanent and you can still be enslaved long after life has left you. Some things about this story are truly scary, and I liked that. <br /> <br />As I said before, the pace gets a bit slow near the beginning, but push through that and the rest of the story reads fast. There isn't much said about Ancelstierre, which I thought could've been more developed as a country so different from the Old Kingdom, but it's not really all that noticeable once you get caught up in the story. The only other bump in the narrative is the switching points of view, an easy writing trap I was a bit disappointed the author fell into. There's no need to leave Sabriel's point of view to move the story. It would've gone just fine without direct input from other characters' minds. <br /> <br />None of that is enough to detract badly from the story, though, (just enough to stop me from giving it five stars) and even if they do throw you out of the narrative on occasion, it's easy to get drawn back in. This is definitely a book I'd recommend to people.

B000002H4C|4.0|There's only one thing as cool as seeing this movie at midnight in the right state of mind, and that's this soundtrack. B000001A3R|5.0|This album is the essence of simple hard, riff-heavy rock, call it `stoner rock' if you will - whatever genre - this will raise the hairs on the back of your neck in a style only the rock gods in the olden days could. This was my first Kyuss album and remains my favourite after going through their discography (which, isn't really much of a feat, it is tragically small). The album's structure is of three pieces, each containing at least three songs, almost creating a medley. At first this structure frustrated me, it wasn't that accessible if I wanted to listen to a part of each long piece, but overall it creates a flow to the album, almost giving it three `movements' each representing different ideas and musically diverse.<br /><br />The first piece kicks of with `Gardenia' through a powerful muddy, down-tuned riff which progresses through different variations until Garcia's vocals kick in. His voice is brutally raw yet melodic at the same time. I've read some reviewers complaining about his lack of variation, but to me his voice is just perfect, complementing the heavy old-school guitars. `Gardenia' is a mighty opening blow, full of crunching riffs that engulf the listener in a thick haze of distortion. `Asteroid' is a superb instrumental, something Kyuss like to throw into thei albums. It's somewhat progressive in style, built around a simple theme with some mighty crescendos thanks to Homme's advanced song structuring.<br /><br />`Supa Scoopa and Mighty Scoopa' and `100 degrees' are typical Kyuss rockers, great riffs and melodies. `Space Cadet' then follows halfway through piece two, and what a tremendous surprise it is, an utterly beautiful moving ballad. The guitar playing is amongst the finest on the album and Garcia's vocals are, I would argue, diverse to the usual delivery - soft and tender. The piece washes over in its seven-minute entirety almost too quickly, fortunately though it leads into my other favourite of the album, the driving `Demon Cleaner'. On this one Garcia's vocals have a dreamy aspect to them, recalling the tripped out desert feel. Along with Homme's relentless riffing, this song is simply stunning.<br /><br />Piece three is probably my least favourite out of the three, but is still a thundering tour-de-force of riffs and melodies. `Odyssey' is one of the most aggressive, confrontational pieces on the album, highlighted by Garcia's overwhelming delivery, launching himself into the lines `once you return from the belly of the beast/ you're never quite the same'. `Whitewater' is a fine way to close the album, a personal highlight for me. It slowly builds to a monumental riff.<br /><br />This album is quite simply powerful, `listen without distraction' it says in the liner notes, I wouldn't worry about that, this is truly engulfing stuff. For fans of old school rock and metal, and fans of metal in general, try this band immediately.s vocals have a dreamy aspect to them, recalling the tripped out desert feel. Along with Homme's relentless riffing, this song is simply stunning.    Piece three is probably my least favourite out of the three, but is still a thundering tour-de-force of riffs and melodies. `Odyssey' is one of the most aggressive, confrontational pieces on the album, highlighted by Garcia's overwhelming delivery, launching himself into the lines `once you return from the belly of the beast/ you're never quite the same'. `Whitewater' is a fine way to close the album, a personal highlight for me. It slowly builds to a monumental riff.    This album is quite simply powerful, `listen without distraction' it says in the liner notes, I wouldn't worry about that, this is truly engulfing stuff. For fans of old school rock and metal, and fans of metal in general, try this band immediately.

B00097DX3U|3.0|Audioslave's self-titled debut was heavy rocking; it was a thunderous album full of monumental riffs and stunning Cornell banshee screams. It also had a lovely subtler side to it, highlighted by some solid ballads. So I had high hopes.<br /><br />`Out Of Exile' was certainly hyped; in various interviews the band seemed most happy with their work, especially Cornell. So I was expecting more of the beastly rocking and the subtler ballad style that seemed to work so nicely.<br /><br />Instead the band hit a kind of middle ground, there are still heavy moments with great riffs, and Morello's soloing may even be better here, but the ballads are weak and simply too often. The rocking sections don't always rock, and the quieter sections leave me wanting more. `Your Time Has Come' is a great opener, after putting the cd in and hearing this, I was already questioning the negative reviews. Then the title track just goes past with its ok hooks, never at any point does it grab my attention, it doesn't have any powerful playing, and it doesn't have any subtle playing. Its just a middle ground rock song. Same applies for the next two tracks, `Be Yourself' becomes very monotonous after a few spins. `Heaven's Dead' is just a slow burning ballad that doesn't burn anything.<br /><br />On the upside (apart from the opener), `Drown Me Slowly' has great energy and the band really seem to connect here. Cornell's vocals complement the raging guitar playing with the panache found on their debut.  `The Worm', while being very simplistic is just a brutal hard-hitter. Cornell's `HALO' screaming is most ravishing. `Man Or Animal', similar story to `Drown Me Slowly', Audioslave laying out the hard rock in style. `Yesterday To Tomorrow' is the only half-decent slow song here, very much a Metallica ballad in sound, but in a good way, the vocal and guitar arrangements are good enough to keep my attention and actually make me enjoy a slower moment, as opposed to pushing the skip button.<br /><br />So, this is a mixed bag to be concise. The rocking moments are good at times, and generally I dislike the ballads. The style of the debut is seemingly lost here, instead of trying to create a `rock classic', I'd much rather see Audioslave lay off the balladry and pummel me with their amazing ability to create power. 3 stars, worth a listen.r /> <br />So, this is a mixed bag to be concise. The rocking moments are good at times, and generally I dislike the ballads. The style of the debut is seemingly lost here, instead of trying to create a `rock classic', I'd much rather see Audioslave lay off the balladry and pummel me with their amazing ability to create power. 3 stars, worth a listen. <br />
0393327655|3.0|A book like this needed to be written in our world today. Unfortunately, this isn't the book that needed to be written.     Harris touches on many of the reasons why we need a book like this, including broad issues (not just faith based terror, there's also faith driven violence and intense social coercion inside the U.S.) and some of the roots for that (the way comments about faith end conversations, so beliefs remain unexamined; and how we are expected to treat all beliefs with equal tolerance and credibility).     As it is, it stops being useful in advancing the conversation because of the absolute insistence on \\"reason\\" as he defines it as the only test, and the underlying axe that Harris seems extremely intent about grinding. Maybe Harris' reasoning leads him to the inescapable conclusion that there's no place for religion in the modern world, but it would help to avoid acting omniscient, and be willing to do a more even handed job of looking at various perspectives.     Dismissing religion as the misguided consolation of idiots and madmen just isn't going to advance the conversation. Equally importantly, an overemphasis on logic shows a rather one dimensional approach to the discussion.     There are lots of things we have theories about, for which the theories are not currently testable by science (like super string theory). There's room for philosophy in our world - but it does need to be discussed and examined. Also, recognize that most of us believe several impossible things before breakfast each day.     Also, it would help to separate out which things are really being done for the sake of religion and which are being done for power and money - whether we're discussing the Crusades or Supreme Court nominees.     Harris should have set aside his absolutist views, and put more emphasis on how to get society to have conversations about what works, in building a life and a culture, and what doesn't work (those unexamined things that we can't seem to discuss today, like how Islamic societies have failed their people).  (...)

B000BJ7BCA|4.0|It is always a struggle to find a movie at the video store for \\"family movie night\\" that both of my elementary school daughters will enjoy and I will, if not enjoy, be able to tolerate.  I have certainly appreciated the effort that many studios have made to make kids' films more enjoyable for parents.  When my younger daughter chose \\"Sky High,\\" I was not terribly optimistic, but Disney actually did a pretty good job making it sort of fun for this GenXer.  More importantly, the younger crowd LOVED it.<br /><br />Will Stronghold (Michael Angarano), the son of two superheroes, Commander (Kurt Russell) and Jetstream (Kelly Preston), is about to start high school.  Will is not going to just any high school.  As the son of superheroes, he will go to Sky High, where he will follow in is parent's footsteps.  However, Will has a secret.  He does not have any super powers, so he is relegated to classes for \\"Sidekick's,\\" and that is obviously a disappointment to his famous father.  At Sky High, Will must deal with everything a \\"normal\\" kid must face while growing up, but, through a series of typically teen-age blunders, discovers he must also face his parents' greatest nemesis, Royal Pain (Mary Elizabeth Winstead).  The future of Sky High and of the entire world depends on Will.<br /><br />Disney used a lot of great tricks to transcend the generational gap in \\"Sky High.\\"  For GenY, some of the costumes, acting, and special effects were very much reminiscent of the wildly popular, live-action, Saturday morning television show, \\"Mighty Morphin Power Rangers.\\"  What boy born after 1978 was not secretly in love with the Pink Power Ranger portrayed by Amy Jo Johnson?  (Confession: When my little sister watched \\"Power Rangers\\" a couple of decades ago, I was sort of into the Pink Power Ranger myself!)  Royal Pain's costume, body movements, secret hideout, and general evil demeanor are a dead-ringer for \\"Power Rangers\\" genre.  For Gen X, a wonderful little trick that I had not seen before, although I have to imagine it has already been employed, is the use of classic, coming-of-age anthems, like, among others, \\"I Melt The World,\\" \\"Save It For Later,\\" \\"Voices Carry,\\" \\"Everybody Wants To Rule The World,\\" \\"And She Was,\\" but had them recorded by contemporary artists.  Heck, I think the entire soundtrack is comprised of `80's remakes.  (I still think The Talking Heads' version of \\"And She Was\\" is superior to that of Keaton Simons, but what would a six-year old care?)  For both Baby Boomers and some early GenXers, the casting of Kurt Russell is sort of an interesting bookend to Russell's Disney career.  I remember going with my parents to local single screen cinema to see Disney's \\"The Computer Who Wore Tennis Shoes\\" and \\"The World's Strongest Man\\" with Kurt Russell playing the teen-age lead.  Appearances by the original television \\"Superwoman,\\" Linda Carter, as well as \\"Kids in the Hall,\\" Dave Foley and Kevin McDonald go a long way to make \\"Sky High\\" ironically humorous for the adult audience.  Nicely done.<br /><br />A film completely appropriate for the younger crowd with just a little cartoonish violence, \\"Sky High\\" is a thumb's up for both kids and parents.  This is the kind of movie that made Disney what Disney was.  If we see more \\"Sky High's,\\" Disney will very soon once again become the entertainment powerhouse it used to be.have to imagine it has already been employed, is the use of classic, coming-of-age anthems, like, among others, \\"I Melt The World,\\" \\"Save It For Later,\\" \\"Voices Carry,\\" \\"Everybody Wants To Rule The World,\\" \\"And She Was,\\" but had them recorded by contemporary artists.  Heck, I think the entire soundtrack is comprised of `80's remakes.  (I still think The Talking Heads' version of \\"And She Was\\" is superior to that of Keaton Simons, but what would a six-year old care?)  For both Baby Boomers and some early GenXers, the casting of Kurt Russell is sort of an interesting bookend to Russell's Disney career.  I remember going with my parents to local single screen cinema to see Disney's \\"The Computer Who Wore Tennis Shoes\\" and \\"The World's Strongest Man\\" with Kurt Russell playing the teen-age lead.  Appearances by the original television \\"Superwoman,\\" Linda Carter, as well as \\"Kids in the Hall,\\" Dave Foley and Kevin McDonald go a long way to make \\"Sky High\\" ironically humorous for the adult audience. One way to describe this record is Duke Ellington writing about trees, bugs and venus fly traps. As a synthesist (ie. synthesizer player), on these albums Stevie Wonder brings the instrument probably as far as it has ever gone as a human, expressive instrument. But always his voice, acoustic piano, drums and bass and found ambient sounds meld with electronic textures to create something nobody had ever done before and people have been copying ever since. Secret Life of Plants has some of his best singing as well, freed from trying to get a \\"hit.\\" In my opinion, this sound cycle is one of the most important recordings of any genre made in the 20th century. B000E1ZBGS|3.0|Though beautifully shot and ably acted, there is too much story in \\"Pride and Prejudice\\" to fit into 2 hours. The film skimps on the relationship between Elizabeth and her father, and flattens the differences between the sisters until they are nearly indistinguishable. Mister Collins, the fusty pastor, is only marginally dull; fiendish Mr. Wickham seems incapable of guile; Lydia Bennet insufficiently silly. The movie gives us little background to appreciate the country-vs-city issues, such as why Darcy and Miss Bingley considered walking so bizarre a mode of transport. And not for a moment did I consider Keira Knightley as someone who could be taken as plain-looking.<br /><br />The sets are quite splendid, however. Even the Bennet's \\"poor\\" country manor, for all its faded and peeling glory, is rendered with great detail. The sountrack however, was so loud and lush and hardworking that it bordered on clich&eacute; -- when it wasn't actually masking important dialog. So much of the film is hurried, with machine-gun dialog that I could not understand. And compensatory touches -- like providing the characters with different outfits or outsized personalities -- were ignored for some reason, perhaps to focus more on the main characters. If so, this was a huge mistake. The charm of P&P is the interplay between the book's many characters and the norms that governed them. To streamline the characters and plot is to take away the story's soul.<br /><br />And no amount of loud music can make up for that.<br /><br />I highly recommend the 1995 miniseries, starring Jennifer Ehle and Colin Firth. It's more than twice as long as this movie, but has to be.

037571457X|5.0|This is a graphic novel that everyone should read.  Marjane Satrapi was only 10 years old when the Islamic Revolution occurred in Iran.  Through simple but powerful pictures and prose, she details what it was like for her to grow up in Iran during that timeframe.  She is taught rebellion by her parents who opposed the Islamic regime and consequently as a teenager she wants to listen to the forbidden music of Kim Wilde, Iron Maiden, and Michael Jackson- even though she knows the penalty for being caught listening to it is severe.  She has to hide behind the veil in public but looks for ways to rebel, including painting her fingernails and wearing hidden jewelry.  Satrapi maintains a sense of humor throughout many portions of the book, including one memorable scene where her father tells the veil-enforcing teacher that the teacher needs to shave her mustache if a female's hair is so stimulating!  However, long after I read this book the first time, one scene haunted me in particular.  Early in the book, a massacre occurs when everyone in a theater is locked in to die while the theater burns to the ground. I think what makes this book particularly powerful to me is that the author is only 1 year older than me and it is only when I compare my life from ages 10-14 with her life that I realize just how much she had to endure.  Highly recommended to all!
0765309408|5.0|Old Man's War is Starship Troopers without teen angst, without the militaristic proselytizing (although the philosophizing in ST was amongst the best parts of the book, forget the horrid movie), with much more humor and with David Brin's concept of humans fighting for their survival in a universe with a multitude of hostile creatures (Startide Rising, Uplift War).   <br /> <br />The concept is simple: if you are 75, would you leave Earth, never to return, and fight for humanity amongst the stars for up to 10 years among the Colonial Defense Forces (CDF) in the face of a 70% mortality rate, in exchange for physical restoration to youthful status, and the ability at the end of your service to settle upon a human colony at the physical age of 25, thereby giving you a second adulthood?  Protagonist John Perry would, and did.   <br /> <br />OMW is essentially the memoir of Perry's first year or so with the Colonial Defense Forces, from leaving Earth as a 75-year old widower with his son and grandchild left behind, to joining the ranks, to accepting a new physique and mindset, to becoming a leader within the CDF.  It deals with aging, rejuvenation, heroism, war with aliens and alien first contacts with humor, swift plotting and no small amount of empathy.  The plot devices are similar to Ender's Game, The Forever War and Starship Troopers -- strange aliens attacking humanity, humans seeking to colonize the stars, otherworldly technology that allows humans to \\"move\\" faster than light-speed, super biological enhancements, etc., but in Scalzi's universe war is not dependent upon inability to understand the aliens (Ender's Game, Forever War), but instead stems from both competition for habitable worlds and the presence of aliens who see humans as a food source. <br /> <br />Scalzi's aliens are diverse and intriguing, from animal-like creatures to inch-high humanoids to nasty slime; but none are more interesting than the Consu, insectoid zealots who are like Heinlein's Bugs and Card's Buggers but who can communicate with humans, believe in a Klingon version of Buddhism (reaching Nirvana through combat), have a Borg-like worldview and have a strange affinity for their victims. <br /> <br />Some very good stuff with action, humor, philosophical introspection and more packed into a short, fast book.

0375507256|5.0|David Mitchell's \\"Cloud Atlas\\" will likely prove to be a challenging if not daunting read for novices, but lovers of the literary novel genre who are experienced in navigating complex thematic artifices and structures, should simply trust their instincts and dive straight in, for there's gold in this magnificent chinese box of six tenuously interrelated, tantalizing vignettes. I'm sure Mitchell wouldn't approve...but I took the unconventional path of taking each of the short stories in turn, completing the reading cycle for one before proceeding to the next, in order to reduce the burden of remembering names and other plot details of six completely disparate tales contemporaneously.     The six stories are individually set in different times, different locations and told using voices and narrative styles that are couldn't be more different. Yet there is a clear integrity and an unmistakeable cohesion in the novel's overall contruct. Though the stories are linked by the thinnest of threads from incidental plot details running through the story chain, thematically they bleed into one another and congeal seamlessly to produce a kaleidoscope of images showing the history of man's inhumanity to man from past through present and into the future. Mitchell's clarion call for humankind to take heed or perish reaches its climax in the cataclysmic, futuristic sixth story and that's the toughest one to navigate through `cos it's narrated in dialect.     Adam Ewing's sojourn through the Pacific bears more than a passing resemblence to Matthew Kneale's classic \\"English Passengers\\" while Robert Frobisher's tale of deceit is deliciously comical. The pace quickens with Luisa Rey's heartstopping escapades, surely the stuff of Hollywood movies. Timothy Cavendish's plight is both social commentary as well as black comedy. Next we find ourselves in Hermit Kingdom where robots yearn to become human beings once they've tasted the forbidden fruit. Different as each of them is from one another, they're all gems and I love them unreservedly and unequivocally.      Mitchell is a genius and \\"Cloud Atlas\\" an astounding literary achievement.  Criminally, it made the shortlist for several book prizes in 2004 but walked away with none that mattered. Never mind, it's a wide and enduring readership that counts and it's heartening to note that after more than 12 months after its original publication, its Amazon sales ranking in the UK is still at a healthy triple digit level. Quite clearly, the reader knows best.

Billy Joel is one of the greatest musicians and songwriters ever and this compilation is a good representation of some of his finest work.

0393327655|5.0|Harris here makes the case that literal belief in ancient myths is doing the world more harm than good, a fact any sane person should be able to appreciate in light of the 911 attacks. When someone sincerely believes they're doing the will of God, there is no horror or atrocity that can't or won't be used towards that will. <br /> <br />Many might think that fundamentalist Islam is the only religion to fear, but Harris credibly argues that any religious belief system, including our comparitively tame modern version of Christianity, can easily lead to fanaticism that could spell the end of free society, and possibly society period. As proof, consider that if the most hardcore elements of the american Christian Right were to have their way in this country, all homosexuals would be in danger of imprisonment just for having consensual sex, any sexually explicit content on television or internet would be illegal, millions of young women would be facing prison terms for having an embryo the size of an almond removed from their bodies, and the scientific establishment would have to rewrite just about every textbook in at least the fields of biology, astronomy, geology, physics, and anthropology so as to make them conform to the ridiculous biblical notion that the Earth and the human species are 6,000 years old. This is not an exaggeration, this is what they actually want (ok, the textbook thing is a bit exaggerated, but not all that much!) -- because they're convinced their \\"God\\" wills it. Religious fundamentalism inexorably leads to severe loss of freedoms, which is frankly downright un-American. <br /> <br />Finally, because I feel it necessary to confront fundamentalist perversions of logic and fact whenever I encounter them, I must address the previous comment that claimed Christianity provided the basis for the ending of slavery. It has always amused me the many times I've come across Christians uttering this patently nonsensical claim, but it has also frustrated me as I have realized just how great the self-delusion must be that these people are under to believe something so backwards. The level of rationalization the typical Christian must engage in in order to make sense of certain aspects of their theology is gargantuan enough, but the level of rationalization necessary to convince oneself that not only was the biblical God opposed to slavery from the very beginning, but that he was ultimately the real reason slavery was finally abolished, is truly too staggering to contemplate. <br /> <br />But let's allow the Bible to speak for itself on the matter of slavery, it happens to be rather uncharacteristically clear and consistent on the subject: <br /> <br />Leviticus 25:45-46 (Old Testament) <br />\\"You may also purchase the children of such resident foreigners, including those who have been born in your land. You may treat them as your property, passing them on to your children as a permanent inheritance. You may treat your slaves like this, but the people of Israel, your relatives, must never be treated this way.\\" [Wow, how's that for equality! But I thought all of us were made in the \\"image of God\\" and therefore have basic rights and dignity endowed by him? Oh, well.] <br /> <br />Exodus 21:2 (Old Testament) <br />\\"If you buy a Hebrew slave, he is to serve for only six years. Set him free in the seventh year, and he will owe you nothing for his freedom. If he was single when he became your slave and then married afterward, only he will go free in the seventh year. But if he was married before he became a slave, then his wife will be freed with him. If his master gave him a wife while he was a slave, and they had sons or daughters, then the man will be free in the seventh year, but his wife and children will still belong to his master. But the slave may plainly declare, `I love my master, my wife, and my children. I would rather not go free.' If he does this, his master must present him before God. Then his master must take him to the door and publicly pierce his ear with an awl. After that, the slave will belong to his master forever.\\" [Honestly, I'm not making this up. It's right there in the \\"Good\\" Book! But wait, there's more!] <br /> <br />Exodus 21:20-21 (Old Testament) <br />\\"If a male or female slave is beaten and dies, the owner must be punished. If the slave recovers after a couple of days, however, then the owner should not be punished, since the slave is the owner's property.\\" [So, not only can we own slaves, but we can also beat them to within an inch of their lives. We have a truly great God!] <br /> <br />1 Peter 2:18 (New Testament) <br />\\"You who are slaves must accept the authority of your masters. Do whatever they tell you--not only if they are kind and reasonable, but even if they are harsh.\\" [Wait a minute, I thought we were morally justified in overthrowing the oppressive slavery in the south against the resistance of the slave owners. Does that mean the Confederacy troops were the \\"good guys\\" in the Civil War after all?] <br /> <br />Titus 2:9 (New Testament) <br />\\"Slaves must obey their masters and do their best to please them. They must not talk back.\\" [I guess a slave fighting for his freedom is out of the question then?] <br /> <br />Ephesians 6:5 (New Testament) <br />\\"Slaves, obey your earthly masters with deep respect and fear. Serve them sincerely as you would serve Christ.\\" [Ok, ok, so a slave should serve his owner just as he would serve God himself? Should the slave make burnt offerings to the owner as well? The vibe I'm getting here is that slave ownership is next to Godliness.] <br /> <br />And that's just a taste of the pro-slavery biblical barbarism. I haven't even presented the verses allowing the selling of your daughter into slavery and the use of virgin females captured in war as sex slaves, but this should be enough to make the point that anyone who honestly believes that this religion is responsible for the abolition of slavery should have his or her brain chemicals checked for proper neurotransmitter balance. <br /> <br />But no one should be the least bit surprised that twisted, perverted logic such as this gets peddled by otherwise bright people who unfortunately believe that a multi-thousand-year-old book of confused myths, written by desert-dwelling barbarians of the distant past, is the divinely inspired bedrock of human morality. The obvious reason Harris wrote his book is to nudge people into re-examining their beliefs in the interest of the future of the entire human race. Can we really survive in the age of doomsday weapons when we have scores of people on the planet who believe in horrifically primitive ancient scriptures which promote cruelty, intolerance, and barbarism -- and which have virtually no relevance to modern life? Isn't it time we put the stories away and finally grow up?

Syracuse University educated you can just see Bubba and Cooter, second cousins, sitting in front of the General Store when Willie (then just Will) rides into downtown Clanton, long hair and all, in his Triumph Spitfire, talking about that 'damncommiejunkieliberalcatholicdeeeeeegenerate' who takes a job at the dying newspaper as a cub reporter.<br /><br />Mr. Grisham is patient and takes his time creating a sentimental (OK, occasionally too sugary) journey for Traynor, funny, sad, and insightful, draping it over a horrific crime of rape and murder that rocked the small town.<br /><br />I admire Grisham, like Lehane and Parker, because they all have a successful formula and yet are unwilling to stay with something safe. Profitable but not very creative.<br /><br />So with \\"Painted House\\" and \\"Bleachers\\" Mr. Grisham steps out and tests the water. Being a Vietnam Vet, Grisham's (Willie's) editorial against the Vietnam War in 1971 brought tears to my eyes. Nicely hung together. 5 stars. Larry Scantlebury

B000002MIB|3.0|In 1993, at the height of grunge and alternative rock, Van Halen released yet another multi-platinum CD with their first ever live album \\"Live: Right Here, Right Now.\\" Compiled from various shows between 1988 and 1993, \\"Live: Right Here, Right Now,\\" focuses mainly on the Sammy Hagar era of the band and Van Hagar's first three albums \\"5150,\\" (1986) \\"OU812,\\" (1988) and most notably \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge\\" (1991). Hagar's renditions of a couple Roth-era songs, a WHO cover, a few Sammy Hagar songs, and a few instrumentals round-out the album.<br /><br />\\"Live: Right Here, Right Now\\" has a lot going for it. Many of these live renditions sound fuller than the studio versions, especially songs from \\"5150\\" and \\"OU812.\\" Hagar's monologues, although at times long-winded, are generally interesting, especially his speech about living in the moment in the middle of \\"Panama.\\"  The instrumentals are more hit-or-miss. And there are A LOT of instrumentals; a drum solo, a guitar solo, and a bass solo. If you're into that sort of thing you will be well pleased with this release. But if you don't care for long instrumentals and solos, you may find them tedious. A cover of the WHO's \\"Won't get fooled again,\\" sounds good, an obvious choice it may be.<br /><br />The biggest drawback of this release is that it focuses exclusively on the Sammy Hagar-era of the band. It would have been far more desirable to have two CDs, the first covering '78-84 shows, (with Roth) and the second covering the Hagar era. But because the Van Halen brothers have always tried to downplay the Roth years and make Van Hagar out to be the definitive Van Halen (see \\"The Best of Both Worlds\\") we get a double-album of the Red Rocker without any Diamond Dave. When the band plays Roth-era material, it sounds good, until the vocals come in. As much as I like Sammy, he never could pull-off singing the Dave songs. While Hagar doesn't butcher the Roth songs, they just sound goofy, i.e. \\"got my ass against the record machine\\"(Hagar's replacement, Gary Cherone, did a terrific job singing all three eras on Van Halen's 1998 World Tour). Another problem with \\"Live: Right Here, Right Now\\" is that there are too many songs from \\"For Unlawful Carnal Knowledge.\\" Even if this had to be a Hagar-only live album, more songs from \\"5150\\" and \\"OU812\\" should have been included.<br /><br />While \\"Live: Right Here, Right Now\\" isn't exactly KISS \\"ALIVE,\\" (1975) it's still a pretty good album. While casual fans are advised to stay away, VH fans, especially fans of Van Hagar will enjoy this release. Hopefully someday an official Roth-era live VH album will see the light of day.'s replacement, Gary Cherone, did a terrific job singing all three eras on Van Halen's 1998 World Tour). While \\"Live: Right Here, Right Now\\" isn't exactly KISS \\"ALIVE,\\" (1975) it's still a pretty good album. While casual fans are advised to stay away, VH fans, especially fans of Van Hagar will enjoy this release. Hopefully someday an official Roth-era live VH album will see the light of day.

B0000029AL|3.0|3.5 Stars<br /><br />With the possible exception of KISS and later Van Halen, no other band is synonymous with great 70s hard rock as much as Aerosmith. With their blues-based boogie grooves, the \\"toxic twins\\" Steven Tyler, (vocals) and Joe Perry, (guitar) along with Brad Whitford, (guitar) Tom Hamilton (bass) and Joey Kramer (drums) produced some of the best rock albums of the 1970s, most notably \\"Toys in the Attic\\" (1975) and \\"Rocks\\" (1976).<br /><br />Often a band's best album is their debut. It is common for a band to tour and tour and tour, perfect a batch of songs, release it on a spectacular debut, and then run out of ideas and have to face the \\"sophomore slump.\\" With Aerosmith, however, the band didn't really get its groove until their third album \\"Toys in the Attic.\\" Aerosmith's 1973 self-titled debut and its follow-up \\"Get your Wings\\" (1974) are good solid albums, but seem rather tepid and underwhelming when compared to the band's mid 70s prime material. While the self-titled debut contains the classics \\"Dream On\\" and \\"Mamma Kin,\\" the rest of the album isn't up-to-par. That's not to say that the self-titled debut only has two good songs and a bunch of filler; as the rest of the album is good, it's just that it doesn't compare with the band's later material. With the self-titled debut Aerosmith found their signature, it's just that the band's writing hadn't yet reached its peak. While the opening \\"Make it\\" and the classic balled \\"Dream On\\" and the rocking \\"Mamma Kin\\" stand as some of the band's best work, the rest of the album is just good, but not great.<br /><br />If you are an Aerosmith fan, by all means, get this album. If you are new to Aerosmith, however, start off with \\"Toys in the Attic\\" and \\"Rocks\\" before buying the debut.

B000002TQV|5.0|It would be hard to find many people who thought Radiohead could do what they did on this album. The first song, 'Planet Telex,' is a worthy first song and it is obvious Radiohead has changed. Many fans who do not like the Ok Computer-present era believe this album is Radiohead's best. I would be hard pressed to disagree. I listened to this album over and over for several days and I still enjoy greatly. For a first timer, this would be the album to start off with to give Radiohead a listen.

B000E33VWW|5.0|Truman Capote was for a time, famous for being famous..Moreso, since Capote had written \\"Breakfast At Tiffany's\\" at an astonishingly precocious age, a title he pirated from a wealthy confidante who told him about a sexual encounter he'd had with a sailor, and the next morning Capote's friend said to his guest, \\"Brunch is on me at the finest restaurant you can name\\", and the seaman said, \\"Well, let's have breakfast at Tiffany's!\\"..Capote, like all resourceful writers salted that away, for that useful rainy day..It was a title in search of a novel..And that's how Capote worked, he imagined a scenario and spent months constructing it in his sub-conscious mind, then went into seclusion and wrote like the devil..Capote stumbled upon the senseless killing of an an upright, God fearing family in Kansas while perusing the backpages of the New York Times, and realized there was sensational value in the story, and intended to write how the murders affected the community, regardless if the perpetrators were ever captured..Capote told his editor he was leaving for Kansas immediately, and would take Harper Lee, author of \\"To Kill a Mockingbird\\", along as his research assistant..Nell, Harper Lee, would prove invaluable to Capote since she had an engaging ability to charm a rural community already on extreme edge since the incident, and was less shocking than Truman upon introduction..Capote met Alvin Dewey, the Bureau agent in charge of capturing the killers and told him he needed carte blanche to the police files, but was not concerned if the killers were found, he only wanted to write how the town was holding up!..Dewey told Capote, \\"Well, I do care, Herb Clutter was my friend\\"..In the end, Capote used his contagious charm to defrost the community, and was granted first person status, above all other journalists covering the crime, in fact Capote wrote a friend, \\"People here initially rejected me, but now I'm practically the Mayor.\\"..When Capote and Nell first spyed Perry Smithand Dick Hickok in court at their arraignment, Capote told Nell, \\"Look, Perry Smith's feet barely touch the ground.\\"..Nell told a friend, \\"Oh my God, this is the beginning of an intense love affair between Truman and Perry\\"..While writing \\"In Cold Blood\\", Truman changed course and realized the article intended for The New Yorker would become a narrative novel, since the subject matter expanded, and his editors agreed..Six years hence in utter agony \\"In Cold Blood\\" was published, and Capote was the recipient of adulation not seen since Hemingway wrote \\"The Old Man and the Sea\\"..The net result became, Capote had the wealth and celebrity to finance his disintegration, and never finished another novel..Capote died alone at the home of Joanne Carson, wife of late night talk show host Johnny Carson at the age of 59, suffering from acute alcoholism and drug addiction, perhaps because he never recovered from the trauma inflicted on himself from \\"expoiting\\" Perry Smith, who died compliments of the state of Kansas, from a hangman's noose, for the shotgun murders of the Herb Clutter family, for a score of 29 dollars, and a transistor radio.

B000002H2H|5.0|Metallica's second studio album Ride the Lightning was released in 1984. It came only one year after their debut Kill `Em All. Although many of the mainstays on Metallica's set list are present on this album, it's sadly underrated. Many Metallica fans consider Master of Puppets to be their masterpiece but all of the elements that make Master a thrash epic are evident in Ride the Lightning. <br /> <br />When one first listens to the album they may wonder if they bought the right album. The opening track \\"Fight Fire With Fire\\" begins with a joyful guitar arrangement that seems more at home on the soundtrack to Bambi. In a moments notice, the faade is dropped and a torrential rain of sixteenth notes punctuated by power chords assaults the listener. James Hetfield mirrors the rhythm guitar part with his vocal, which lyrically is about the concept of M.A.D, or mutually accepted destruction. One highlight of this song apart from the furious rhythm guitar would have to be the dual guitar harmony part that comes in near the finish that is reminiscent of the work of Iron Maiden. <br /> <br />The title track is thematically about a man that is on death row dreading his execution in the electric chair. While the chorus is catchy, the rest of the song is rather uninspired and consists of little more than eighth notes on the low E string being played at a moderate pace. <br /> <br />\\"For Whom the Bell Tolls\\" is one of the three tunes off of this record that nary a Metallica concert goes without. One of the main highlights of the song is Cliff Burton's bass playing. Also, the main riff of this song is one of the most identifiable riffs in all of heavy metal. <br /> <br />\\"Fade to Black\\" was a big departure from everything Metallica had done previously. This is Metallica's version of a power ballad. Unlike the rest of Metallica's songs up to this point which had all implemented a heavily distorted rhythm guitar, \\"Fade to Black\\" included a finger picked passage for the intro and verse sections. The song contains three tasteful solos by Kirk Hammett which are much more melodic than most of his work at the time and is far better than his \\"noodling\\" on Kill `Em All. The song was such a departure from their regular sound that it prompted many fans to call the band sellouts. The song also received flack from the PMRC for its lyrics about suicide. Many fans have stated in Metallica's defense that the song helped them in rough times in their lives. <br /> <br />\\"Trapped Under Ice\\" is a good song but when compared to the other stellar tracks on the album, it just doesn't compare. <br /> <br />\\"Escape\\" is lyrically about a person being who they want to be instead of letting others control their life. <br /> <br />\\"Creeping Death\\" is another standout track that no Metallica performance goes without. The song is about the plagues depicted in Exodus. The song seems anything but holy when the band starts chanting \\"Die\\" over Hetfield's thundering rhythm guitar. The song is concluded by one of Hammett's more memorable solos and then Hammett and Hetfield joining in for some more Iron Maiden-esque harmony guitar parts. <br /> <br />\\"Call of Ktulu\\" is an epic instrumental based upon the story of Cthulhu by H.P. Lovecraft. The song is very creepy as it employs great use of chromatics in many of the riffs. For the last half of the song, Kirk Hammett's lead guitar pyrotechnics takes center display.  <br /> <br />Ride the Lightning is perhaps Metallica's finest album. Even thought there are some tracks which obviously don't stand out as much as the album's premiere tracks, they are all great songs, better than what most other bands in the genre are capable of. Every fan of heavy metal needs to have this album in their collection. <br /> <br />
0761957553|5.0|Very nice books - well written. <br />Strongly recommended for PhD students. <br /> <br />Tom Spentzas, MD <br />Memphis, TN
B000BJS4TO|5.0|This is it. The follow-up score to \\"Schindler's List\\" that everyone was expecting in 1994, but never got. It's passionate, beautiful, ominous, painful and features remarkable solo performances. <br /> <br />Countless reviews before me have mentioned it, but Williams was going for the feel of a river in this score, and it definitely translates to the listener. The music flows seamlessly from track to track, from gentle gushing and playful bouncing to deep and dark, culminating in the appropriately-titled \\"Confluence\\". But enough with the water metaphors! The two recurring themes are \\"Sayuri's Theme\\" and \\"The Chairman's Waltz\\", with the former the central idea of the score. Some tracks revolve around the theme, but in others it dips in quietly and leaves so it never feels overused. The Waltz sounds almost European - very reminiscent of \\"Jewish Town\\" from \\"Schindler\\", but it's still hauntingly beautiful. Other highlights include the extremely catchy \\"Going To School\\" and, of course, the \\"Yep, that's Williams\\" track, \\"Confluence\\". The whole score builds up to it, but it's still restrained enough to retain dignity. Though it never reaches those unchained heights from \\"Schindler's List\\", it never feels like it should have. <br /> <br />Like Yo-Yo Ma said in an interview, Memoirs is definitely a Williams score; not because it sounds like his other scores or he reused ideas, but because all of these worlds are a part of him, so he is a part of them. A brilliant score in an astounding year from the Maestro.
0156027321|5.0|Having finished Life of Pi yesterday, and then reading about 100 reviews here, I've decided to throw my oar in the water, so to speak. <br /> <br />Could it be that the reason \\"we will believe in God\\" after reading this book (I believe Martel wrote that phrase with tongue-firmly-in-cheek)is that this fable is an allegory for Christianity, Hinduism, Islam, and possibly (thanks to the person who pointed out the Tsimtsum reference) kabbalistic Judaism -- all separate, but equally, represented? <br /> <br />I can speak to the Christian allegory I read.  I don't know enough about Hinduism or Islam to understand the allegorical references here.  But I do believe they're here.  I believe that Yann Martel has told us unequivocally that he finds value in all three religions, and I believe they're all \\"hidden\\" in this book. Doesn't a prince ride a tiger in one of many famous Hindu art pieces?  Please, could well-read and deeply-faithful Hindus or Muslims please respond here so we might know your thoughts? <br /> <br />As a Christian,let me share what I see Martel imputing into this fable: <br /> <br />The Life of Pi is the life of Everyman or Everywoman.  Pi, of course, is without beginning or end, just as we are, just as our souls will always be -- eternal and of great significance. <br /> <br />If orange is the color of Hinduism and the green the color of Islam, I vote for blue as the color of Christianity.  In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.  Heavenly blue is also the historic color of faith, as well as representational of the Virgin Mary during the Gothic and Renaissance periods.  Pi floats between blue sea and sky. <br /> <br />Pi, like Noah, has been forced to live in his private ark, taking care of the animals.  In the beginning, God told man to have dominion over all the birds of the air and the fish of the sea and the animals on land. Pi is saddened as he learns to kill and eat flesh, but he must do it in order to survive.  There is an order andregimen to his days, just as God said after the flood (hmmmmm) that daytime and nightime, planting and harvest, the seasons, would never cease. <br /> <br />More than that, the lifeboat is really its own island, just as all of us live as \\"islands\\" alone, bobbing along the mostly blue surface of this planet. (With no apologies to John Donne . . .)    <br /> <br />Each of us must come to terms with our own loneliness, our own sin and brutal nature that travel as part of us through life (Richard Parker). We are all sinners-saints and equally divided, just as the lifeboat is divided into two separate areas.  Our brutal nature scares us and in fact energizes us as we try to keep it at bay. Pi, in the book, thanks Richard Parker for keeping him alive.  It's doubtful that a less fearful creature would have kept him so occupied in building a raft, securing enough water, finding food to feed both of them, being attentive, etc. <br /> <br />The survival manual in the lifeboat is similar to the \\"instruction books\\" we have been given to navigate the waters of life -- the Bible, the Bhagavadgita (sp?), the Koran, the Torah. Of course, each of us believers reverences our own particular book, but these books exist and chart the way for each believer. <br /> <br />What about the French cook, also blind, also floating on his own island?  Interesting that Pi's influences (Pondicherry) and even his name (Piscine) are half-French, half-Indian and that these two parts also meet in the water.  Perhaps Pi's imagination summons up a cook because of his hunger? The French represent the old rule of India -- the \\"old man\\" -- who dies off with that encounter. I think of the old hymn \\"Amazing Grace\\":  I once was lost but now am found, was blind but now I see.  Point made. <br /> <br />The floating green island, I believe, is an allegory of Eden, untouched, unblemished, filled with creatures who are innocent and have no fear. Don't forget the tree in the middle of this island who eats man.  Godexpressly forbid man to eat of the fruit of the \\"tree of the knowledge of good and evil\\" or he would die.  Someone did eat of this fruit and Pi -- all of us --are the worse for it. The Garden of Eden was polluted by sin and so became a Venus fly-trap, a flesh-eating creature. The Earth sprouted thistles and weeds, which forces all men (and women)to labor and to work hard for our daily bread.  Finally, it consumes us all at the grave. <br /> <br />Pi survives to tell the tale. He is ressurected after a near-death, returning to tell us both a tale of heaven and a tale of hell. <br /> <br />I'm sure when I reread this book one day I will see much, much more. Please, fellow-readers, Hindus and Muslims, will you enlighten us as to what you see of your faith \\"hidden\\" in this fable?  I would love to learn even more of the intricacies of this book and the careful weaving of timeless truths and stories that it encompasses!  Bravo, Yann Martel!
B00006WUWQ|5.0|We bought this for our brother. He loved it. THe print's great and so is the sound system-it's crisp. Also, it completes the collection. Great buy for the price!
B0002OERI0|5.0|American Idiot was written to tell a story (a \\"punk rock opera\\"). The title of the album in itself, and it's art, explains of what's to come. There's much confusion to actually what this album and all of its songs mean, and it's questioned to what it could mean. I'm following, basically, with my own outlook, and from information from the band.<br /><br />DEFINITIONS IN THE STORY:<br /><br />J./JOS/the Idiot of America: The Jesus of Suburbia Tunny: Random person met on the street who Jimmy befriends The Underbelly: JOS/Jimmy's group of friends Mom and Brad: JOS' parents. The way that JOS refers to his father as Brad, could mean that is father is gone and Brad is a stepfather, which would explain why he's calling him by name.<br /><br />AMERICAN IDIOT<br /><br />The title track of the album. Basically, there's a confused, disoriented, angsty kid wrapped around a world of misconception and he has nowhere to go and feels hopeless and miserable. So this kid, the Jesus of Suburbia, is just crying out an anthem for the world to hear, screaming miserably \\"Don't wanna be an American Idiot...\\" He sees that he's stuck in this 'redneck agenda' and there's not a thing he can do to change it.<br /><br />JESUS OF SUBURBIA<br /><br />Everyone on the album has their own track. Jesus of Suburbia basically introduces us to the Jesus of Suburbia, how he was brought up in rage, and love, his atmosphere, friends, and basic general information. Part I, JOS, is just an introduction. \\"I'm the son of rage and love, the Jesus of Suburbia...\\"...Part II, City of The, is just a crying out for help, hating his town, his city, and his overall miserable life that he lives. Part III, I Don't Care, is properly named and is about just that. JOS' apathetic screams of pain and how he just doesn't care about anything anymore. Part IV, Dearly Beloved, is JOS asking if what he's feeling is natural, how he can get out, and if anyone can understand...Tales Of Another Broken Home, Part V, is basically the end of the anthem. JOS is fed up, and just decides to quit town and quit the life that he's living. \\"I don't feel any shame, I won't apologize. When there ain't NOWHERE you can go. RUNNING AWAY from pain, when you feel victimized, tales from another broken home\\"...and he just leaves.<br /><br />HOLIDAY<br /><br />So JOS has just left town and he's living his life on the streets (Hear the sound of the falling rain...). He's speaking outloud and acting in vein :P, but it seems like he's talking himself into the fact that running away was the right thing to do. Explaining his reasons of discontent to himself. He still feels alone, and shunned from society, but it seems he feels a little more self-confidence, and happiness out on the road. It is also remotely political with the whole \\"Zeig heil...\\" thing, but it's basically just JOS yelling out and expressing his own dead beliefs onto the world. Like screaming into mid air. Also, to go 'on holiday' is said to be like, a vacation. So this is basically like an escape, a runaway. This leads us into Boulevard of Broken Dreams.<br /><br />BOULEVARD OF BROKEN DREAMS<br /><br />JOS is out alone, on the cold streets, nothing to do, nowhere to go. The happiness has worn off and he walks alone. Everyone's asleep, no one can hear him, no one cares, and he just walks...<br /><br />ARE WE THE WAITING?<br /><br />Still, alone, living it rough. JOS plays tricks in his mind, and you can see his slowly losing his sanity. He even starts to not believe who he is anymore. He's not the king of his local 711 out on the streets, where no one knows who he is...he's not the Jesus of Suburbia anymore. He's just...there.<br /><br />Now is where the controversy starts. The album picks up into an angry, purely amazing, anthem about the ever-so-lovely St. Jimmy. Now, people have said, and this sounds pretty true, that the JOS is just pushed over the edge, turned into this new you punk named St. Jimmy. Basically, pushed off of the deep end into schizophrenia. Green Day, actually has stated, that JOS meets this kid, St. Jimmy, on the street somewhere, but that's questionable. I'll leave the interpretation up to you.<br /><br />ST. JIMMY<br /><br />Fast, upbeat, so hardcore. St. Jimmy...the patron saint of the denial. Tough, rough, not afraid to kill. The run of the mill punkkid times 70. The hardest, baddest guy around. He's lived his life on the streets, knows all, sees all. Lies, and pretty cocky to boot. He can actually be seen as a foil to JOS, who's totally innocent and callow going into this thing.<br /><br />GIVE ME NOVACAINE<br /><br />JOS meets Jimmy and becomes close with him. They do everything together, hang around together and JOS depends on Jimmy to keep him sane, without knowing anyone else. Give Me Novacaine is basically his experimentation and how Jimmy introduces him to everything to ease the pain of everyday life.<br /><br />SHE'S A REBEL<br /><br />While on the streets, Jimmy and JOS meet a rebel girl named Whatsername. As described in She's A Rebel, she's holding on JOS' heart like a hand grenade. For JOS, it's love at first sight. It's a basic introduction to the girl, and a new twist in JOS' heart strings. New feelings, new mindset, new atmosphere.<br /><br />EXTRAORDINARY GIRL<br /><br />Again, about Whatsername. JOS' feelings for her, what he thinks of her, etc...<br /><br />LETTERBOMB<br /><br />After getting close with Whatsername, there is an eventual breakup. The beginning \\"Nobody likes you, everyone left you...\\"...is Whatsername taunting JOS, and writing him a goodbye letter. She explains that JOS doesn't care enough, and that he isn't who he thinks he is. \\"You're not the Jesus of Suburbia. The St. Jimmy is a figment of, your father's rage and your mother's love, that's made the idiot america\\"...she's explaining that JOS has turned into what he's always hated and she leaves him. \\"Well she said I can't take this place, I'm leaving you behind. She said I can't take this town I'm leaving you tonight...\\"<br /><br />WAKE ME UP WHEN SEPTEMBER ENDS<br /><br />JOS is alone again. Lost his friends, the only girl he ever loved, he's out of home, out of job, and back where he started, sad and alone on the streets. He describes himself as innocent, or at least he was, and he just didn't last. They broke him down, and he's just dead inside. This is also, on a more personal note, a side song about Billie Joe's late father, who died years ago (September 1982), when Billie Joe was 10. Both explanations apply.<br /><br />HOMECOMING<br /><br />JOS has nothing left to do. He's been on the streets. He stands alone again. So where else to go? Home. Part I, the Death of St. Jimmy. He's leaving the streets, he's going back, he's leaving Jimmy behind. He realizes that turning away wasn't the answer, and he's gained nothing from it except knowledge that life is no better in a different atmosphere. He hoped for too much, and got nothing in return. St. Jimmy kills himself, in a sense, in JOS' mind he's gone. Still, there's no one who cares, and nobody cares. Part II, East 12th St, tells us that JOS met and accepted conformity, got a job, and is just in his own world as people move around him. He'd rather be out and around with 'the underbelly', his friends. He feels trapped. Alone, and again, must get away. \\"This lifelike dream ain't for me\\"...Part III, Nobody Likes You. He's still depressed about losing Whatsername, as he waits for her to return, but no luck. All of his dreams at this point are shot to hell, as her voice still pounds in his head \\"NOBODY LIKES YOU, EVERYONE LEFT YOU...\\" Part IV, Rock 'N Roll Girlfriend, in the inlay, is shown as a postcard from \\"Tunny\\"...who seems to be another person JOS met while on the streets. Tunny explains that he's living it up where he is, and the rebel life he leads, while JOS is rotting with his dead end job, in his dead end life. Part V, We're Coming Home Again, is JOS accepting things. He's coming to the realization of everything and everyone, and is just accepting it. He comes home. It's left on a confusing note. He's not sure if he's happy or sad, he's just home, living, and he just...is.<br /><br />WHATSERNAME<br /><br />After being home, and just living in normality, he still regrets losing Whatsername. It's been so long, he can't even remember her name. He wonders what happened to her, and can only remember. All he has is his memories of her. The album ends with him still trying to forget \\"If my memory serves me right, I'll never turn back time, forgetting you, but not the time.\\"...He doesn't regret living his life on the streets, using it as a learning experience, but still tries to forget Whatsername, and the pain that she put him through, and vice versa.. She said I can't take this town I'm leaving you tonight...\\" <br /> <br />WAKE ME UP WHEN SEPTEMBER ENDS <br /> <br />JOS is alone again. Lost his friends, the only girl he ever loved, he's out of home, out of job, and back where he started, sad and alone on the streets. He describes himself as innocent, or at least he was, and he just didn't last. They broke him down, and he's just dead inside. This is also, on a more personal note, a side song about Billie Joe's late father, who died years ago (September 1982), when Billie Joe was 10. Both explanations apply. <br /> <br />HOMECOMING <br /> <br />JOS has nothing left to do. He's been on the streets. He stands alone again. So where else to go? Home. Part I, the Death of St. Jimmy. He's leaving the streets, he's going back, he's leaving Jimmy behind. He realizes that turning away wasn't the answer, and he's gained nothing from it except knowledge that life is no better in a different atmosphere. He hoped for too much, and got nothing in return. St. Jimmy kills himself, in a sense, in JOS' mind he's gone. Still, there's no one who cares, and nobody cares. Part II, East 12th St, tells us that JOS met and accepted conformity, got a job, and is just in his own world as people move around him. He'd rather be out and around with 'the underbelly', his friends. He feels trapped. Alone, and again, must get away. \\"This lifelike dream ain't for me\\"...Part III, Nobody Likes You. He's still depressed about losing Whatsername, as he waits for her to return, but no luck. All of his dreams at this point are shot to hell, as her voice still pounds in his head \\"NOBODY LIKES YOU, EVERYONE LEFT YOU...\\" Part IV, Rock 'N Roll Girlfriend, in the inlay, is shown as a postcard from \\"Tunny\\"...who seems to be another person JOS met while on the streets. Tunny explains that he's living it up where he is, and the rebel life he leads, while JOS is rotting with his dead end job, in his dead end life. Part V, We're Coming Home Again, is JOS accepting things. He's coming to the realization of everything and everyone, and is just accepting it. He comes home. It's left on a confusing note. B0002F6BRE|4.0|Nonsense.  ELF is pure nonsense.  A baby that crawls inside Santa's bag of toys on a fateful Christmas Eve and thus is raised by the elves in the North Pole.  As the human (Buddy the Elf, of course) grows, he can't help but notice he's \\"different.\\"  And finally, Buddy is told the somber truth--that he is not an elf, that he is a human, and that his father (who happens to be on Santa's \\"Naughty List\\") resides in Manhattan.  And so Buddy sets off, on foot, (after saying goodbye to various animated North Pole pals) to the Big Apple, where mayhem reigns supreme upon his arrival.<br /><br />Like I said:  nonsense.  But funny nonsense.  Will Ferrell plays Buddy with simultaneous naivete and tongue-in-cheek raunchiness; he more than carries this film on his bright green shoulders.  James Caan is pure vanilla bland as Buddy's reluctant, long-lost father, while Bob Newhart is at his deadpan best.  The plot is hokey, the ending syrupy (as is Buddy's diet) and contrived, yet ELF had me laughing in spite of my curmudgeonly self.  The holy grail of entertainment is escapism, and ELF takes the viewer directly into the story and doesn't let go until the last giggle.<br /><br />This is a movie not only appropriate for Yuletide cheer, but anytime one needs a raucous laugh.  My only concern is my utter confusion:  ELF's elves are little munchkin midgets, while the elves in \\"Lord of the Rings\\" are tall and stoic.  Wow.  Guess I've gotta brush up on my elfology.<br /><br />--D. Mikels

B000001ES9|4.0|While they were just getting their foot in the door with their 1973 self-titled debut album (1974 in the U.S.), Rush showed glimpses of what they could (and would!) evolve into on successive releases. Starting out as a blues-driven hard-rock act, Rush combined fantastic musicianship, integrity, and a love of music that set them apart from most bands. Combining the styles of bands like The Who, the Yardbirds, and Led Zeppelin, the resultant fusion was a great framework for the genre-defying progressive rock that Rush would create throughout the 1970s. <br /> <br />Rush is a fantastic release, though by no means their most solid work. Most of Geddy Lee's lyrics on this album are a bit generic, and look almost comical when one views the lyrics that future drummer Neil Peart wrote on most of their songs once he joined the band before the Fly By Night album was released in early 1975. <br /> <br />1. Finding My Way - A solid and rocking opener to kick off the album, this track starts off with a bluesy riff, which increases in volume as the measures repeat. The intro lyrics sound quite a bit like something Robert Plant would belt out on a Led Zeppelin song, but I forgive Rush for this being their first album. Bands start off by playing what they know and love, and the bands that inspire them oftentimes find their way (no pun intended) into the early works of a new band. The solo is solid and the post-solo riff is tight. All in all, this is a great intro track and the recording sounds fantastic to this day: 11 out of 13 (84.6%). <br /> <br />2. Need Some Love - A short track with a fast tempo and cheesy lyrics. I dig the vibe of this song, even if the lyrics are sub-par. The drumline following the second chorus is simplistic but solid, and John Rutsey was not a bad drummer by any means. The guitar solo is short and sweet. This song: 10 out of 13 (76.9%). <br /> <br />3. Take A Friend - This track fades in slowly with a driving drum beat and a sweet guitar lick which repeats for many measures before the rhythm guitar kicks in to begin the first verse. The chorus showcases the seed of vocal harmony that would become an intregal part of Geddy Lee's fantastic vocals in future releases. Yet another guitar solo graces this song, and it fits in nicely with the rest of the song. That's one thing about Rush is that the individual parts don't sound out of place, whether it's a flashy drum, bass, or guitar solo. Rating: 11.5 out of 13 (88.5%). <br /> <br />4. Here Again - The longest track on the album, clocking in at seven and a half minutes, Here Again closed out the first side of the original vinyl album. A slow-tempo song with a groovy rhythm guitar line which graces a large portion of the track time. Geddy's vocals sound more mature on this track, though it is spotty. You can tell that Geddy's voice wasn't fully mature, and may have still been changing from his teenage years. This song makes you want to sit back, relax, and enjoy some good rock music. The guitar solo near the five minute mark stretched out for a solid minute and a half, and is smooth as silk. It has a nice echo added, and doesn't sound out of place at all. The second solo near the end of the song is great, and closes out the track perfectly. This song gets: 10.5 out of 13 (80.8%). <br /> <br />5. What You're Doing - A neat little ditty with a cool guitar riff. John Rutsey's drumming is solid in this track, and Geddy's wisecracking lyrics aimed at naysayers are bang-on. The guitar solo is top-notch and Rutsey's snare roll is solid as can be. The closing is a bit much with a few false endings, but the mini guitar solo makes up for it. Survey says: 11 ouf of 13 (84.6%). <br /> <br />6. In The Mood - This track is one of my favorite Rush tunes, and boasts a good intro guitar riff, which carries the rhythm of the tune during the verses. Lyrics are generic, but Geddy's vocals are good. Drums keep up the beat, as usual, but nothing too flashy from Rutsey. Alex Lifeson belts out ashredding solo which is a fine tribute to blues form. This song gets: 12 out of 13 (92.3%). <br /> <br />7. Before And After - A peek into what Rush would evolve into in later albums, Before And After is a solid track which begins with a somber guitar riff and a slow tempo. Lots of harmonics and clean chords. Distortion kicks in at about a minute, and once the verse kicks in, the song shifts tempo up a bit. Geddy's vocals are varied, and the simple chorus (Yeah...Yeeeeaah) is quite effective. Alex unfolds another fantastic solo in this song which sounds perfectly in place with the rest of the song. I give it: 9.5 out of 13 (73.1%). <br /> <br />8. Working Man - A classic Rush tune, which gets a lot of air play on classic rock stations to this day. The big hit song off this album, which is surprising since it clocks in at seven minutes. A good and heavy guitar riff opens the song and carries the verses. A groovy little breakdown cuts the song in half, and the closing guitar riff/solo are fantastic. The boastful conclusion bids you good tidings until the next release. All in all: 11 out of 13 (84.6%). <br /> <br />Overall, this is a great classic rock album, and a good addition to your collection whether you're a casual or serious Rush fan. A more digestible form of Rush for the casual listener, and a glimpse into the roots of the prog-rock juggernauts they would become for the more serious music fan in the Rush spectrum. Overall rating of 'Rush': 10.8 out of 13 (83.1%).

B00008AWOG|5.0|First off, I am NOT a metal expert in any sense of the word. As a matter of fact when I first heard \\"death\\" metal growls I laughed. I thought they were just so lame and corny. I digress, Damnation has no growls and it was right up my alley. \\"Still Life\\" does have scorching death vox,as if Akerfeldt summoned them from the very pits of hell. Also Michael sings in a \\"clean\\" voice that is (IMO)the best voice in any genre of music. I would say 60% death vox and 40% clean, something like that. The concept attracted me, for it's about a man who is kicked out of his community by the town \\"council\\" for rebelling against the Christian theocracy held so dear in the town. In the process he loses his true love Melinda. The music and lyrics on \\"Still \\"Life are about his return and attempt to retrieve Melinda. The music could not be better in conveying this concept. As far as the growls I looked at the vocals as another instrument(for that's what the voice is)in conveying the tone and composition, that has helped me to not only like the death vox, but appreciate them as well!!! This will take a few listens to be fully revealed, be patient. Opeth is not just a \\"metal\\" band. They are all extremely gifted musicians in the truest sense of the word. You would be doing yourself a disservice for not listening to this band because of the death vox. Have an open mind and you will be rewarded. The song Benighted is quite possibly the most beautiful song I have ever heard. The way the clean vocals come in to the music is stunning. Opeth and Pain of Salvation are two metal bands that are completely unique and wonderful. They have certainly set the bar high, for all metal bands to come. All hail the mighty Opeth, Still Life is an absolute masterpiece. Peace.

0553801503|3.0|I agree with some of what many of you have said. i think publisher pressure had a lot to do with the decision to release the book in this format, but after reading interviews with Martin i think there is more to it than that.<br /><br />  Basically what happened is that while writing this latest book he ran into a problem and had a decision to make. He could go the established route or try something different...and he chose to try something different. The problem that arose is that he had created a number of new characters to introduce in the book along with the established ones. He reached a point however, where he realized he would not be able to tell all of their stories in one book. He felt that rather than either tell only the newer characters stories or only focus on the previous characters would be a disservice to the fans.<br /><br />  Now, here comes the choice: either he, A. focuses on all the characters and cuts all their stories short, or B. Pick half of the characters and tell their complete stories, then later tell the other half in the next book. He obviously chose B. Now, i have to give Martin some credit. On paper this must have looked good and he honestly thought he was making the best choice for the fans. He obviously didn't mean to hurt the fans who hated this book. He took a 50/50 shot and in my view, it bombed. I personally think he made the wrong choice.<br /><br />  First of all, experimenting with literature is risky. I hate to say this Mr. martin but at this stage in the history of writing, if there is a literary convention that is never used...there is a Good reason for it! Especially when you change formats from your previous books in a series.<br /><br /> The really sad part to me is that it looks like the fans that hated this book because of the format will probably not like the next book any better. i am sorry to say all this because I think G.R.R. Martin is one of the most gifted fantasy authors of all time and i'd hate to see that reputation tarnished all because of a shot in the dark editing decision. but thats just me.
